questions.text: A 30-year-old man was found wandering on the streets shabbily dressed with no shoes on, in the middle of winter. He was admitted to the inpatient psychiatric unit and was stabilized on antipsychotic medication. After getting discharged, he stopped taking his medication as he thinks he doesn't suffer from any mental illness. He has a past history of multiple relapses after stopping his medication. Which of the following medications is the best one for this patient to be maintained on?
questions.solution:
There is strong evidence that without continuous treatment, virtually all schizophrenic patients relapse within 12 to 24 months. Injectable depot medications such as haloperidol decanoate and fluphenazine decanoate are effective in decreasing the rate of relapse in patients who are not compliant with oral medication.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh Edition, page no 1053

questions.text: A 24-year-old sexually active male presented with a single, hard genital ulcer. His VDRL test was positive and the infection was confirmed with FTA-ABS. The patient was not compliant with penicillin therapy, and hence his disease progressed. He later developed a loss of joint position and fell down when asked to walk in a straight line with his eyes closed. This implicates a lesion in which of the following?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes syphilis, caused by the bacteria Treponema Pallidum. When the infection progresses to tertiary syphilis and involves the organ systems, Tabes Dorsalis is seen in the spinal cord.

It exclusively involves the dorsal column pathway.

Thus, loss of position, vibration, and proprioception is lost. As a result, the sense of position is only by the visual inputs. So, when the patient is asked to close his eyes, his sense of position is completely lost and the patient tends to fall. This is called positive Romberg's test

Sense of vibration etc is not lost in spinocerebellar lesions

Lateral spinothalamic tract involvement causes contralateral loss of temperature and pain

Corticospinal tract is a descending tract and causes hemiplegia if involved.


Source- BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, page 49

choices.text: Does not sensitize the heart to catecholamines
Has a minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) value of 0.75

questions.text: Isoflurane is an Inhalational anaesthetic with the following features:
questions.solution:
Isoflurane causes a decrease in tidal volume with either a normal or slightly raised respiratory rate - the result is a slight rise in PaCO2. It does cause catecholamine sensitization but less than that seen with halothane or enflurane. Isoflurane is pungent and causes some respiratory irritation, making inhalational induction difficult. It has a MAC value of 1.15 (halothane is 0.75)

Reference: Pinnock CA, Lin ES, Smith T. Fundamentals of Anaesthesia, 2nd Edn. Greenwich Medical Media Ltd, 2003, Section 3, p 597

questions.text: Adenoidectomy may help improve all of the following conditions except
questions.solution:
Velopharyngeal insufficiency may result from adenoidectomy, especially in the presence of a submucous or frank cleft of the palate. This is characterized by rhinolalia aperta and the reflux of liquids into the nasal airway. Adenoidectomy has been recommended for the treatment of recurrent otitis media, otitis media with effusion, airway obstruction caused by enlarged adenoid tissue, and pediatric sinusitis.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 44 Diseases of the Oral Cavity, Oropharynx, and Nasopharynx page no 1032

questions.text: Harry, a 20-year-old dancer presents with difficulty in abducting his arm. When asked to exert forward pressure on his arm, the following was seen. Match the muscle implicated in this case and its nerve supply.
questions.solution:
The image above depicts Winging of Scapula, which is seen due to paralysis of Serratus anterior muscle. The medial border and inferior angle of the scapula become unduly prominent when the person exerts forward pressure, or the examiner gives resistance. The person is unable to do any pushing action and can also not abduct his shoulder joint.

Serratus Anterior-

  1. Origin- by 8 digitations from the upper 8 ribs
  2. Insertion- medial border of scapula
  3. Action- protraction of the chest wall, abduction of the shoulder from 90-180 degrees, along with trapezius, forced inspiration
  4. Nerve supply- C5,6,7 roots- long thoracic nerve(of bell)

Source- BD Chaurasia's human anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume-1 page 48

choices.text: Witness is examined by the defense lawyer
Objective of cross-examination is to weaken the case of the opponent
There is no time limit to cross-examination

questions.text: Which of the following statements does not apply to cross-examination in a court of law?
questions.solution:
Leading questions are allowed in a cross-examination according to Sec. 143 IEA. However, they are not allowed during the direct examination conducted by the summoning counsel.

In the event that the Judge is satisfied that the witness is hostile, leading questions may be allowed during direct examination.

Leading questions (Sec. 141 IA) are defined as questions that suggest an answer that is favorable for the case of the summoning counsel or in alignment with their claim.

Other options:

Options 1, 3, 4 - In cross-examination, the witness is examined by the defense lawyer or adverse party with an objective to elicit favorable facts to their case, to test the accuracy of the witness statements, to unearth new or old facts, and also, to discredit the witness.

While leading questions are allowed in cross-examination, the Judge can disallow questions that are indecent (Sec. 151 IA) or questions asked with an intention to insult or offend the witness in any form (Sec. 152 IEA).

There is no time limit to the duration of cross-examination.

References: Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice 5th edition Page Nos, 11

questions.text: A lady had a trauma to the neck. The X-ray is attached. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hangman's fracture is a fracture of pars interarticularis of C2 and slip oi C2 over C3 as shown in the image.

Hangman's fracture: It is a fracture through the pedicle and lamina of the C2 vertebra, with subluxation of C2 over C3, sustained in hanging

  • Jefferson's fracture involves Atlas (C1).
  • Clay shoveler fracture involves the spinous process of the lower cervical spine.
  • Sciwora usually occurs in children <8yrs old. It is a spinal cord injury without obvious

radiological abnormality.

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 3

questions.text: Kaposi sarcoma is associated with
questions.solution:
HHV-8, which infects B lymphocytes, macrophages, and both endothelial and epithelial cells, appears to be causally related not only to KS and a subgroup of AIDS-related B cell body cavity-based lymphomas (primary effusion lymphomas) but also to multicentric Castleman disease, a lymphoproliferative disorder of B cells. The association of HHV-8 with several other diseases has been reported but not confirmed.

Reference: Jameson J, Fauci AS, Kasper DL, Hauser SL, Longo DL, Loscalzo J. eds. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20e New York, NY: McGraw-Hill: Page 1365

questions.solution:

questions.text: At autopsy, Pancreas appears grey, enlarged, and nodular, and microscopy shows localized deposits of calcium. This finding is most similar to an adaptive change that occurs in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient's history suggests chronic pancreatitis, which is confirmed by the dystrophic calcification seen on microscopic examination.

Congenital CMV infection disrupts normal cellular differentiation and apoptosis mechanisms, resulting in diffuse inflammatory damage and necrosis in tissues. Developing nervous tissue is particularly susceptible to damage, and the damaged areas undergo dystrophic calcification, resulting in the distinctive periventricular calcification seen in congenital CMV infections.

Unlike metastatic calcification, dystrophic calcification is localized to damaged or necrotic tissue and occurs in patients with normal serum calcium and phosphate levels. Further examples of dystrophic calcification include calcific aortic stenosis, calcified atherosclerotic plaques, and psammoma bodies.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 31

choices.text: Magnesium hydroxide and bicarbonate are recommended
Gastric lavage and emetics are contraindicated
Administration of milk or egg white is beneficial

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the treatment of inorganic acid ingestion is not true?
questions.solution:
The use of alkaline agents such as magnesium hydroxide or bicarbonate is not recommended for the treatment of inorganic acid (sulphuric acid, nitric acid, hydrochloric acid) ingestion.

The rationale behind the usage of these compounds was that acid can be neutralized by an alkali. However, alkali administration can result in an exothermic neutralization process coupled with gas production in some cases. This could lead to further damage in hollow viscus structures (esophagus, stomach) with a possibility of perforation and further extension of injury.

Other options:

Option 2 - Gastric lavage and emetics are contraindicated in the treatment of inorganic acid ingestion. This is to avoid further backflow of

the acid as well as prevent full-thickness ruptures of the gastric or esophageal structures. Complications may also include peritonitis and

mediastinitis due to acid spillage, laryngeal spasm, and respiratory distress.

Option 3 - Administering prophylactic antibiotics is recommended, especially in cases of suspected or evident perforation. Viscus perforation can lead to gastrointestinal bacterial seeding in the peritoneal or mediastinal spaces with subsequent inflammation (peritonitis, mediastinitis).

Option 4 - Initial course of action in a case of inorganic acid ingestion includes acid dilution by giving milk, water, or aluminum hydroxide gel. Demulcents such as egg white or starch water may also provide some benefits by forming a protective layer over the damaged mucous membrane.

References: Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice 5th edition Page No. 457

questions.text: A 39-year-old female presents with a breast lump. Her family history is notable for breast cancer in her mother and maternal aunt. A mammogram of her left breast is shown. Genetic analysis reveals a mutation on chromosome 17. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is breast cancer in the setting of an underlying BRCA1 mutation. BRCA1 is located on chromosome 17 and mutations or deletions of the gene increase the risk of breast and ovarian epithelial cancers.

In this female patient with a breast lump, breast cancer should be on the differential diagnosis. The significant maternal family history of breast cancer and the early age of presentation (< 50) suggests an underlying genetic disease contributing to increased cancer risk. Mutations or deletions in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 tumor suppressor genes are the most common genetic causes of early breast cancer. BRCA1 and BRCA2 are found on chromosomes 17 and 13, respectively. In addition to increasing the risk of breast cancer, these mutations also increase the risk of ovarian cancers of epithelial origin such as serous cystadenocarcinoma.

Other Options:

Option B: BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations do not increase the risk of endometrial carcinoma. Most risk factors for endometrial carcinoma involve high levels of estrogen exposure, such as obesity, polycystic ovary syndrome, and nulliparity. Genetic risk factors include Lynch syndrome.

Option C: BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations do not increase the risk of granulosa-theca cell tumors.

Option D: BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations do not increase the risk of uterine leiomyosarcomas.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 189

questions.text: A mild mentally retarded 9-year-old girl was brought to your office for a complaint of acne. Her past history is significant for having her first (afebrile) seizure last year. Her mother reminds you that she has a faint birthmark on her hip that is pale and becomes more prominent in the summer when the child's skin tans. Examination of this area reveals a 5 cm oval patch that is hypopigmented. Which condition would she most likely have?
questions.solution:
Children with tuberous sclerosis (tuberous sclerosis complex, TSC) can develop nasolabial fold angiofibromas (commonly referred to as adenoma sebaceum). These can be mistaken for acne in an adolescent and are seen in over 80% of adolescents with TSC. Other cutaneous findings include peri- and subungual fibromas, ash leaf spots (hypomelanocytic macules), and shagreen patches. Skin findings are seen in 75% of cases of tuberous sclerosis. Tuberous sclerosis can also have CNS cortical defects and 'tubers', which may be foci of seizure activity. The 'tubers' have a classic periventricular distribution. Mental retardation is very common in varying degrees.

Sturge-Weber syndrome (also known as leptomeningeal angiomatosis) is a port wine stain, typically with V1 or V2 distribution, with an underlying leptomeningeal blood vessel dysplasia. These dysplastic vessels will typically result in underlying cortical atrophy. This cortical atrophy can be a nidus for seizures and can be seen on a CT scan of the head.

Neurofibromatosis, type 1 is a polymorphous neurocutaneous syndrome. The most common findings are café au lait spots, which may be present at birth and worsen during puberty.

Ref: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 2877

choices.text: Right gluteus maximus and left gluteus medius
Right gluteus medius and left gluteus minimus

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male presented with the following gait on walking.

If the pelvis dips on the right side, which of the following correctly describes the implicated structure?
questions.solution:
A positive Trendelenburg sign usually indicates weakness in the hip abductor muscles:gluteus medius and gluteus minimus.



Positive and negative Trendelenburg sign

A positive test is one in which the pelvis drops on the contralateral side during a single-leg stand on the affected side. This can also be identified duringgait: compensation occurs by side flexing the trunk towards the involved side during the stance phase on the affected extremity.

Clinically relevant anatomy

Gluteus medius and minimus are the primary abductors of the hip. When fully weight bearing they act to abduct the femur away from the mid-line of the body and provide stability of the hip and pelvis.

Technique

The patient is asked to stand on one leg for 30 seconds without leaning to one side. The patient can hold onto something if balance is an issue. The therapist observes the patient to see if the pelvis stays level during the single-leg stance. A positive Trendelenburg Test is indicated if during unilateral weight bearing the pelvis drops toward the unsupported side

Source- BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume 2, page 74

questions.text: Which of the following type of respiratory failure occurs due to alveolar hypoventilation?
questions.solution:
TYPE II RESPIRATORY FAILURE

This type of respiratory failure is a consequence of alveolar hypoventilation and results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition, chapter 293

Presence of synchronous/metachronous colorectal or another hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)-related tumor
Crohn-like lymphocytic reaction, mucinous/signet ring differentiation, or medullary growth pattern) diagnosed in a patient before age 60

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 13-year-old African American boy eats fava beans. Two days later, he becomes pale and begins to complain of back pain. Which of the following figures best demonstrates the likely appearance of this patient's red blood cells?
questions.solution:
Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency causes episodes of hemolytic anemia secondary to oxidative stress caused by oxidizing agents such as fava beans. The peripheral blood smear will show characteristic bite cells as shown in Option D.

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder with an increased prevalence among individuals of African, Mediterranean, and Middle-Eastern descent. It causes a decrease in NADPH in red blood cells which leads to hemolytic anemia due to poor RBC defense against oxidizing agents such as fava beans, sulfonamide, and primaquine. This can lead to a hemolytic crisis which is characterized by fatigue, weakness, back pain, pallor, jaundice, and splenomegaly. The peripheral blood smear of a patient with G6PD deficiency will show characteristic Bite cells demonstrated in Option D and result from the phagocytic removal of Heinz bodies by splenic macrophages.

Other Options:

Option A: Figure A demonstrates an acanthocyte (spur cell) that is associated with liver disease and states of cholesterol dysregulation such as abetalipoproteinemia.

Option B: Figure B demonstrates a red blood cell with basophilic stippling which is associated with thalassemias, anemia, chronic disease, and lead poisoning.

Option C: Figure C demonstrates a teardrop cell that is associated with bone marrow infiltration such as myelofibrosis.

Source: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 147

questions.text: A 13-month-old child is noted to be at the 25th percentile for weight, the 10th percentile for height, and less than the 5th percentile for head circumference. She was born at term. She was noted to have a small head at birth, to be developmentally delayed throughout her life, and to have required cataract surgery shortly after birth. She currently takes phenobarbital for seizures. Which of the following would most likely explain this child's small size?
questions.solution:
The developmental delay, intrauterine growth retardation (including microcephaly), cataracts, seizures, hepatosplenomegaly, prolonged neonatal jaundice, and purpura at birth are consistent with a congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) or toxoplasmosis infection. Calcified brain densities of CMV typically are found in a periventricular pattern; in toxoplasmosis, they are found scattered throughout the cortex.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 1592

choices.text: En bloc excision with structural allograft reconstruction
En bloc excision with wrist fusion using vascularized fibular autograft
Curettage, application of liquid nitrogen, and polymethylmethacrylate

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with swelling and pain in the right wrist. The symptoms have progressed over the last 6 months and she has noted a decreased range of motion of the wrist joint. Figures A and B show the histology. What is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is presenting with a giant cell tumor (GCT) of the right distal radius with preservation of the cortices and joint line. The best treatment option would be extensive curettage with adjuvant liquid nitrogen and polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA).

GCT is a common benign bone tumor that has some malignant characteristics. Approximately 5% of patients have metastasis to the lungs, which should prompt routine chest radiographs.

Surgical treatment usually involves extensive curettage with local adjuvant therapy, which includes liquid nitrogen, phenol, argon beam, and PMMA. Utilizing PMMA had the added benefit of being employed with other local adjuvants prior to placement, as well as the potential to reveal any local recurrence as a lytic lesion at the bone-cement interface.

Reference: maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 239.

choices.text: Cleaving alpha-1,6 glycosidic bonds from glycogen
Creating alpha-1,6 glycosidic bonds in glycogen

questions.text: A 12-year-old male presents after two days of tea-colored urine which appeared to coincide with the first day of cricket practice, where he was excessively fatigued after a set of drills accompanied by pain in his muscles. A blood test revealed elevated creatine kinase and myoglobin levels. A muscle biopsy was performed revealing large glycogen deposits and enzyme histochemistry showed a lack of myophosphorylase activity. Which of the following reactions is not occurring?
questions.solution:
The male most likely has McArdle's disease which is due to a myophosphorylase deficiency. The reaction that is not occurring in this individual is the breakdown of glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate by myophosphorylase.

McArdle's disease is an autosomal recessive, type V glycogen storage disease resulting from a deficit of muscle phosphorylase. As a result, the muscles are unable to break down glycogen into single glucose monomers. This leads to the clinical presentation of muscle weakness/cramps upon exertion and myoglobinuria ('tea - colored urine') due to rhabdomyolysis. Another form of phosphorylase deficiency is Hers disease (Type VI) which is due to a lack of hepatic phosphorylase; it presents as hepatomegaly and fasting hypoglycemia.

Other Options:

Option A: The conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose is catalyzed by glucose-6-phosphatase which is deficient in von Gierke's disease. von Gierke's disease presents with hepatomegaly, severe hypoglycemia, hyperlipidemia, hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis.

Option C: Cleaving alpha-1,6 glycosidic bonds from glycogen requires the debranching enzyme, amylo-alpha 1,6-glucosidase, which is deficient in Cori's disease. Cori's disease presents with hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia, and on histology, these patients have abnormal glycogen structure.

Option D: Creating alpha-1,6 glycosidic bonds in glycogen requires the branching enzyme, amylo-1,4-1,6 transglucosidase, which is deficient in Anderson disease. Anderson's disease presents with hypotonia and cirrhosis.

Source: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 147

questions.text: A patient with small, shallow erosions has punched out appearances over the pressure-bearing area of soles as shown in the figure. What is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pitted keratolysis (PK), also known as keratolysis plantare sulcatum, is a skin disorder that affects the stratum corneum of the plantar surface. It is caused by Gram-positive bacteria that may show filamentous and coccoid structures.1 Responsible agents include Corynebacterium sp., Micrococcus sedentarius, and Dermatophilus congolensis. All these bacteria open small tunnels in the stratum corneum

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 31

questions.text: Anil, a 1-year-old child was brought to the pediatric clinic with complaints of hypoxia and cyanosis, which were relieved when he was made to sit in a 'knee to chest position. His chest x-ray is given below. What could be the cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of cyanotic heart disease and its exacerbation relieved by 'knee to chest' position and a classical 'boot shaped' heart on chest x-ray suggest Tetralogy of Fallot.



It occurs due to the anterior displacement of a spiral septum in the truncus arteriosus during the development of the heart. The aorticopulmonary septum (also called the spiral septum, or aortic septum in older texts) is developmentally formed from the neural crest, specifically the cardiac neural crest, and actively separates the aorta and pulmonary arteries and fuses with the interventricular septum within the heart during heart development



The spiral septum in the truncus arteriosus develops in such a way that the AP septum does not form longitudinally. If it displaces anteriorly, it leads to overriding of the aorta, as seen in TOF.



Other options-

Non-spiral course of spiral septum leads to Transposition of great vessels, ie- blood from RV-Aorta and blood from LV-Pulmonary trunk

Persistence of Septum Primum leads to open fossa ovalis, and leads to Atrial Septal Defect

A defect in the AV cushion can lead to VSD.


Source- textbook of clinical embryology, Vishram Singh, 12 edition, page 196

questions.text: A pregnant patient develops chicken pox at 30 weeks of gestation- She has a fever and rashes.She is not responding to antipyretics and cold sponging.She has difficulty in breathing.What should be the next best step ?
questions.solution:
Chickenpox in a pregnant woman is more dangerous than in children

Woman is likely to develop pneumonia

The majority of women will respond to conservative management- antipyretics, cold sponging, and rest If she has a severe infection- Acyclovir needs to be started

Acyclovir can cross the placenta but for the sake of the mother one should start T. Acyclovir

Varicella zoster virus vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine- contraindicated in pregnancy.

A pregnant woman gets exposed to an affected person-

If there is no h/o prior chicken pox or immunization→Serological testing for VZV→Susceptible (IgG negative) - VariZIG (Varicella zoster immunoglobulin) is given to the mother within 96 hours of exposure

Can be given up to 10 days

This immunoglobulin will prevent infection in the mother

In our case, as she is already affected there is no role of VariZIG.

As her gestational age is 30 weeks- chances of fetal infection are very rare

Max risk of transmission- 13 to 20 weeks

Mother gets chicken pox just before or during delivery- Neonatal varicella syndrome

Max. risk if delivery occurs 5 days before or up to 2 days after the rash

Ref: ICOG-campus-maternal-infection-2018

questions.text: The active form of vitamin D is-
questions.solution:
• The active form of Vit D is 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol.
  • Cholecalciferol is formed in the skin and converted to 25 hydroxycholecalciferol in the liver. This is hydroxylated in the kidney to form 1,25-dihyroxycholecalciferol.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition, Page no 1007

questions.text: A 54-year-old man began taking large amounts of a multivitamin supplement after he read on the internet that it may help to prevent gout attacks. A CT scan of the abdomen shows an 8-mm stone in the right ureter. Microscopic examination of a urine sample shows bipyramidal, envelope-shaped crystals. The increased serum concentration of which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Vitamin C toxicity can result in calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis because vitamin C is metabolized to oxalate, and an increased serum oxalate concentration predisposes to stone formation. In particular, men with risk factors for nephrolithiasis, such as this patient with gout and type 2 diabetes mellitus, are at higher risk of stone formation secondary to excess vitamin C intake. Additional manifestations of vitamin C toxicity include dental erosions (due to the demineralizing activity of vitamin C), nausea, and vomiting, as seen in this patient. Diarrhea and fatigue may also be seen.

Vitamin C toxicity also increases dietary iron absorption and thus increases the risk of developing iron toxicity.

Source: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 968

choices.text: The cells will now produce heme
The cells will not produce heme since they lack mitochondria
The cells will not produce heme because they lack cytosol
The cells will not produce heme because they lack nucleoli

questions.text: Which of the following is true for mature red blood cells?
questions.solution:
Mitochondria are necessary for heme synthesis, and mature red blood cells (RBCs) do not contain mitochondria. Accordingly, the cells will not be able to produce heme due to a lack of mitochondria.

The synthesis of heme involves a series of biochemical steps. Some of the required steps occur in the cytoplasm, but some of the steps occur only in the mitochondria. Under ordinary conditions, all heme synthesis occurs in the progenitor cells prior to RBC maturation. During maturation, RBCs lose their mitochondria, and thus can no longer produce heme. Heme synthesis occurs in most cells of the body; however, it cannot occur in mature RBCs because they lack mitochondria.

Other Option:

Option A: The cells will not produce heme as they lack the necessary mitochondria.

Option C: RBCs have cytosol.

Option D: Nucleoli are not directly needed for heme synthesis

Source: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 360

choices.text: Is increased by increasing blood pH
Produces a metabolite with muscle relaxant activity

questions.text: Pick the false statement in regards to the metabolism of atracurium
questions.solution:
Hofmann elimination probably accounts for 40% of the elimination of atracurium. The metabolites do have minor neuromuscular blocking properties and bradycardia has been reported in association with their use. Degradation is slowed by hypothermia and acidosis.

Ref: Pinnock CA, Lin ES, Smith T. Fundamentals of Anaesthesia, 2nd Edn. Greenwich Medical Media Ltd, 2003, Section 3: Chapter 8

questions.text: A 54-year-old bedridden patient for 1 month is to be checked for fluid collection in the peritoneal recesses. Which of the following is the most common site for accumulation in such a patient?
questions.solution:
Bedridden patients being supine, the most dependant site is the right subhepatic recess, or the hepatorenal pouch of Morrison is the dependant site. In a standing position, the rectovaginal pouch of Douglas is the most dependent site.

Paraduodenal recesses are common sites for internal hernias

Source- BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume 2, page 270

choices.text: Posterior Cricoarytenoid- Abduction of vocal cords
Interarytenoid muscle- Adduction of vocal cords

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect match between muscles of the larynx and their actions?
questions.solution:
Cricothyroid is a tensor of vocal cords, not a relaxor. When it contracts, the arch of the cricoid moves up and the lamina moves down, thus causing the arytenoids to move down as well. This movement lengthens vocal cords and thus causes an increase in tension.

The posterior cricoarytenoid is the only muscle causing the abduction of vocal cords, which is needed for respiration. Thus, it is called the safety muscle of the larynx.

All muscles of the larynx are supplied by Recurrent laryngeal nerves, except cricothyroid, which is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve.

Source- BD Chaurasia's human anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume-3 page 286

questions.text: What is the major apolipoprotein most directly affected by Statins?
questions.solution:
Statin medications most directly lower low-density lipoprotein (LDL) levels. The major apolipoprotein on LDL is B-100.

Statin medications inhibit HMG-CoA reductase, an enzyme required for hepatic cholesterol synthesis, and primarily reduce levels of LDL in the blood. When cholesterol synthesis is inhibited, the liver upregulates LDL receptors in order to get cholesterol from the LDL in the blood (dietary cholesterol). As a result, LDL is removed from the blood and LDL levels are lowered. The major apolipoprotein on LDL is ApoB-100. ApoB-100 is found on VLDL, IDL, and LDL. ApoB-100 binds the LDL receptor and mediates the endocytosis of LDL.

Other Options;

Option A: ApoA-I activates LCAT which catalyzes the esterification of cholesterol. It is not found on LDL.

Option B: ApoB-48 mediates chylomicron secretion and is not found on LDL.

Option D: ApoC-II is a cofactor for lipoprotein lipase cofactor and is not found on LDL.

Source: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 220

questions.text: Varun had shellfish at a local restaurant three days back. He comes into the clinic with a complaint of multiple episodes of loose watery stools soon after it. It was also discovered that other people who had food from that restaurant had similar symptoms. What is the most likely cause of viral diarrhea in these adults?
questions.solution:
Norovirus may be the most common infectious agent of mild gastroenteritis in the community and affect all age groups.

Norovirus-

Non-enveloped, Icosahedral RNA virus

Infectious dose: 10 - 100 viral particles

Route of infection: fecal-oral, aerosolization

Incubation period: 12 to 72h, illness last 12 - 60 h

Clinical features: loose watery stools without blood, mucus, and leukocytes.

Diagnosis: PCR

Reference: Harrison edition 19 p1285

choices.text: Finding high-grade dysplasia mandates further intervention
High-dose proton pump inhibitor therapy will likely cause regression of the mucosal abnormalities
The incidence of these lesions has increased in the era of potent acid suppression
The patient has a high risk of coexisting cancer

questions.text: A 62-year-old gentleman who had a history of chronic abdominal pain, heartburn, and dyspepsia underwent an upper GI endoscopy for evaluation of peptic ulcer disease. Tongues of reddish mucosa extending proximally from the gastroesophageal junction into the esophagus were noted. Biopsies of these areas demonstrate columnar metaplasia. All of the following statements regarding this diagnosis are true except
questions.solution:
Barrett metaplasia is the most serious complication of GERD. It has a strong association with the subsequent development of esophageal adenocarcinoma. The incidence of these lesions has increased, not decreased, in the era of potent acid suppression.

Barrett metaplasia is endoscopically recognized by tongues of reddish mucosa extending proximally from the gastroesophageal junction or histopathologically identified by the finding of specialized columnar metaplasia. Barrett metaplasia can progress to adenocarcinoma through the intermediate stages of low- and high-grade dysplasia. Due to this risk, areas of Barrett metaplasia, and especially any included areas of mucosal irregularity should be extensively biopsied. No high-level evidence confirms that aggressive antisecretory therapy or antireflux surgery causes regression of Barrett's esophagus or prevents adenocarcinoma. Although the management of Barrett's esophagus remains controversial, the finding of dysplasia in Barrett's esophagus, particularly high-grade dysplasia, mandates further intervention. In addition to the high rate of progression to adenocarcinoma, there is also a high prevalence of unrecognized coexisting cancer with high-grade dysplasia. Nonetheless, treatment remains controversial.

Esophagectomy, intensive endoscopic surveillance, and mucosal ablation have all been advocated. Currently, esophagectomy is the gold standard treatment for high-grade dysplasia in an otherwise healthy patient with minimal surgical risk. However, esophagectomy has mortality ranging from 3%-10%, along with substantial morbidity. As a result of these factors and the increasing evidence of the effectiveness of endoscopic therapy with purpose-built radiofrequency ablation devices, many now favor this therapy as a preferable management strategy.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition, Chapter 316

questions.text: Refsum disease is due to the accumulation of?
questions.solution:
Phytanic acid is a branched-chain fatty acid that is normally converted to pristanic acid by α-oxidation. An autosomal recessive defect in α-oxidation is responsible for Refsum disease, which can manifest with scaly skin, shortening of the 4th toe, impaired vision (due to cataracts or retinitis pigmentosa), sensorineural hearing loss, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy.

Mitochondria are the primary site for the β-oxidation of unbranched long-chain, medium-chain, and short-chain fatty acids, but mitochondrial enzymes cannot break down branched-chain fatty acids (BCFAs) or very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs). BCFAs (e.g., phytanic acid) must first undergo α-oxidation, a process that occurs exclusively in peroxisomes and removes the side groups from BCFA. Similarly, VLCFAs must first be shortened to long-chain fatty acids by peroxisomal β-oxidation. Refsum disease, as seen here, is caused by defective α-oxidation of BCFAs in peroxisomes. Other processes that occur in peroxisomes include catalase enzyme reactions (e.g., ethanol catabolism), D-amino acid catabolism, and the synthesis of cholesterol, plasmalogen, and bile acids.

Source: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 205

choices.text: Increased allolactose levels bind to the repressor
Increased cAMP levels result in binding to the catabolite activator protein
Decreased cAMP levels result in poor binding to the catabolite activator protein
Transcription of the lac Z, Y, and A genes increase

questions.text: E.coli has the ability to regulate its enzymes to break down various sources of energy when available. It prevents waste by the use of the lac operon, which encodes a polycistronic transcript. At a low concentration of glucose and the absence of lactose, which of the following occurs?
questions.solution:
At a low concentration of glucose, cAMP levels rise resulting in cAMP binding to the catabolite activator protein (CAP). This enhances the activity of RNA polymerase, but since lactose is absent, the repressor is still bound to the lac operator.

The lac operon allows for E. coli to effectively digest lactose and glucose without wasting extra energy when one is absent. In the presence of glucose, cAMP levels are low; therefore, cAMP binding to CAP is reduced. At a low concentration of glucose, increased cAMP levels result in binding to CAP, which enhances the activity of RNA polymerase. In the presence of lactose, a metabolite of lactose called allolactose binds to the repressor protein resulting in a conformational change that removes the repressor from the lac operator. This allows RNA polymerase to transcribe the lac genes. In the absence of lactose, the repressor binds tightly to the lac operator preventing RNA polymerase from transcribing the genes. At a low concentration of glucose and the presence of lactose, the repressor is removed from the operator and CAP enhances the activity of RNA polymerase.

Other Options:

Option A and D: Although levels of cAMP would be elevated resulting in increased RNA polymerase activity, the repressor protein would still be bound to the DNA due to the absence of lactose. Thus, there would be no transcription of the lac Z, Y, and A genes.

Option C: At a low concentration of glucose, cAMP levels would be increased, not decreased.

Source: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 607

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after stepping on a piece of broken glass. Physical examination shows a 3-cm, ragged laceration on the plantar aspect of the left foot. The physician uses hydrogen peroxide to clean the wound. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of this disinfectant?
questions.solution:
Hydrogen peroxide oxidizes cell membrane lipids, intracellular proteins, and DNA by forming hydroxyl free radicals. It is used in wound disinfection and as a surface disinfectant and is active against bacteria, yeasts, fungi, viruses, and spores.

Source: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 957

questions.text: The data on the correlation between obesity and Diabetes had a strong positive skew. A biostatistician wishes to report the measures of central tendency just by understanding the skew in the data. Which of the following can be expected for this data set?
questions.solution:
A positively skewed data set with a long tail on the right affects the mean the most, followed by the median, and finally the mode. This results in a mean greater than the median which is then greater than the mode.

The 3 most commonly used measures of central tendency are the mean, median, and mode. The mean is the sum of all values divided by the total number of values. The median is the middle value when the data is organized in ascending or descending order. If there are 2 middle values, they are averaged. Finally, the mode is the most commonly repeated value. Depending on the skew of the data or the number of outliers, each measure of central tendency is affected differently. While the mean is most affected by outliers, the mode is least affected by outliers.

Source: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60

questions.text: A patient with resected Ileum is most likely to have which of the following physical exam findings in the long-term?
questions.solution:
The distal ileum is the primary site of vitamin B12 absorption (in the form of B12-intrinsic factor complex).

Vitamin B12 deficiency can present with symmetric neurological deficits, including limb weakness and ataxia. Vitamin B12 is a cofactor of methylmalonyl-CoA mutase and methionine synthase, both of which are necessary for proper neuronal function. The terminal ileum is the primary site of vitamin B12 absorption and therefore resection of this structure, as seen in this case, can result in symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency unless properly supplemented.


Source: Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 502

choices.text: Negative staining of tumor cells for thyroglobulin
Replacement of thyroid cells by normal squamous epithelium
Reduced number of functional thyroid cells
Disorganized proliferation of mature thyroid cells

questions.text: Which of the following changes would be most consistent with anaplasia?
questions.solution:
Anaplasia is the loss of cellular differentiation.

Anaplasia is a process in which cells lose their function and structural differentiation. They may resemble primitive, undifferentiated cells of the tissue they originated from and manifest as large cells with several nuclei or a single large nucleus.

Thyroglobulin is a precursor to thyroid hormones that are produced by mature thyroid cells and stored in the follicles of the thyroid. Undifferentiated (i.e., anaplastic) thyroid cells lose their ability to produce thyroglobulin. A negative stain for thyroglobulin would, therefore, be a sign of anaplasia.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 31

questions.text: Which of the following IPC sections deals with causing foeticide in a pregnant woman with an intent to prevent a developed child from being born alive?
questions.solution:
IPC 315 deals with the intent to prevent a child from being born alive or to cause its death after birth. The pre-requisite associated with this IPC is that the fetus must be in an advanced stage of development that would make it sufficiently capable of leading an extrauterine existence. The offender is liable to punishment consisting of imprisonment for up to 10 years.

Other options:

Option 1 - IPC 313 deals with the causation of miscarriage of a woman with a child (and/or quick with a child without her consent. Only the person causing the abortion is liable to punishment.

Option 3 - IPC 312 deals with the causation of criminal abortion (no therapeutic indication to do so) with the consent of the pregnant woman. Both the pregnant woman and the abortionist are liable to punishment.

Option 4 - IPC 314 deals with the death of a pregnant woman from an act intended to cause miscarriage. In such a case, the abortionist/offender is liable to punishment including imprisonment of at least 10 years and a fine of up to 2 lakh rupees. If the act of miscarriage was undertaken after conducting a prenatal sex determination (female fetus confirmation), the offender is liable to life imprisonment and a fine of up to 2 lakh rupees.

References: Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice 5th edition Page No 387

questions.text: A 60-year-old female chronic bedridden patient was admitted to the neurosurgical department. The patient is having full-thickness skin loss with tissue destruction over the greater trochanter area. The patient is a known case of diabetes mellitus. What should be the line of management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Surgical management of pressure sores follows the same principles involved in acute wound treatment. The patient must be well motivated, clinically stable with good nutrition, and adhere to the preventative measures advised postoperatively. Preoperative management of the pressure sore involves adequate debridement, and the use of vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) may help to provide a suitable wound for surgical closure (see below). The aim is to fill the dead space and to provide durable sensate skin. Large skin flaps that include muscle are best and, occasionally, an intact sensory innervated area can be included (e.g. extensor fascia lata flap with a lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh). If possible, use a flap that can be advanced further if there is recurrence and that does not interfere with the planning of neighboring flaps that may be used in the future.

Reference: love and bailey 27th edition page 30

questions.text: A biopsy of a lymph node reveals aggregates of follicular architecture, and cytogenetic analysis shows a t(14;18) translocation. The protein most likely responsible for the patient's condition does which of the following?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is consistent with that of follicular lymphomas. The oncogene Bcl-2 is found in 80-90% of follicular lymphomas. Bcl-2 inhibits apoptosis.

Follicular lymphoma presents as painless lymphadenopathy. Minor B-cell proliferation forms follicular aggregates that replace normal lymph node architecture. The disease is most commonly found in adults and may progress to large B cell lymphoma. The t(14;18) translocation is found in 80-90% of follicular lymphomas. The Ig-heavy chain locus of chromosome 14 is fused with BCL2 on chromosome 18, producing bcl-2 (B-cell lymphoma 2) overexpression.

Other Options:

Option A: p53 and c-myc are two proteins that regulate passage through the cell cycle.

Option B: p53 is a protein that can activate DNA repair proteins.

Option C: Microtubules compose the cytoskeleton during mitosis.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page

Number 441

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the shock index?
questions.solution:
Option A) C) and D) Since heart rate and systolic BP individually are not accurate at identifying hemorrhagic shock and because the traditionally taught combination of tachycardia and decreased systolic BP does not always occur together, the shock index (SI), which uses these two variables together, was developed. SI is defined as heart rate divided by systolic BP. However, SI does not consider the diastolic BP, and thus a modified SI (MSI) was created. MSI is defined as heart rate divided by mean arterial pressure. As MSI rises, this indicates a low stroke volume and low systemic vascular resistance, a sign of hypodynamic circulation.

Reference: Sabiston 21 ed pg 51

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the treatment of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria?
questions.solution:
A major advance has been the introduction in 2007 of a humanized monoclonal antibody, eculizumab, which binds to the complement component C5 near the site that, when cleaved, will trigger the distal part of the complement cascade leading to the formation of the MAC.

With C5 blocked, the patient is relieved of intravascular hemolysis and of its attendant consequences, including hemoglobinuria. In the majority of those patients who needed a regular blood transfusion, the transfusion requirement is either abolished or significantly reduced.

For many PNH patients, eculizumab has meant a real improvement in the quality of life, as well as a decrease in complications, particularly thrombosis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition, chapter 96

questions.text: A professor measures the plasma concentration of the drug over time after IV and then after oral administration. There is no statistically significant difference in the dose-corrected area under the curve (AUC) for the two routes of administration. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this finding?
questions.solution:
Bioavailability describes the rate and concentration at which the drug appears in circulation and is expressed as a percentage of the dose that was initially administered. In this case, oral administration of the drug shows no statistically significant difference in the dose-corrected AUC from intravenous administration, indicating that this drug has near 100% bioavailability.

Isosorbide mononitrate is an oral medication that dephosphorylates myosin light chains in venous smooth muscle cells. Unlike some other nitrates, isosorbide mononitrate does not undergo first-pass metabolism by the liver and thus has approx. 100% bioavailability. An oral form of isosorbide mononitrate is available and is used in the treatment and prevention of angina pectoris due to coronary artery disease.

Source: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 15

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents with a 1-month history of fatigue and intermittent fevers. He has experienced a few episodes of bleeding from his gums after the fatigue started. A physical exam reveals conjunctival pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, and numerous bruises on his body. Which of the following genetic translocations is most likely associated?
questions.solution:
This patient with fatigue, conjunctival pallor, bleeding, and hepatosplenomegaly with Auer rod containing myeloblasts most likely has acute promyelocytic leukemia, which is associated with a 15;17 translocation.

Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) is a form of acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) that is caused by a 15;17 translocation. This translocation leads to the production of a fusion protein involving the retinoic acid receptor that is normally required for myeloblast maturation. Like other forms of AML, this disease presents with fever, fatigue, and hepatosplenomegaly. Furthermore, disruption of normal blood cell development can lead to signs of pancytopenia including anemia, infection, and bleeding.

Other Option:

Option A: The 8;14 translocations would be seen in Burkitt lymphoma; however, this would present on biopsy with a starry-sky appearance rather than with Auer rods on a peripheral blood smear.

Option B: The 9;22 translocations would be seen in chronic myeloid leukemia, which can also present with fever, fatigue, and splenomegaly; however, it would not demonstrate Auer rods on a peripheral blood smear.

Option D: The 14;18 translocations would be seen in follicular lymphoma; however, this disease would present with painless lymphadenopathy rather than constitutional and pancytopenia symptoms.

Source: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441

questions.text:

questions.text: Mainstay of treatment of uveitis-
questions.solution:
Uveitis is a condition characterized by inflammation of the uvea, which is the middle layer of the eye. Treatment for uveitis depends on the underlying cause of the inflammation, but the mainstay of treatment is usually the use of anti-inflammatory medications and Cycloplegics.

Corticosteroids, either in the form of eye drops or oral medication, are often the first line of treatment for uveitis. These medications work by reducing inflammation and suppressing the immune system.

Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and immunosuppressive drugs may also be used in the treatment of uveitis, particularly in cases where corticosteroids are not effective or have side effects.

In addition to medication, the treatment of uveitis may also involve addressing any underlying systemic conditions, such as infections or autoimmune diseases.

Reference: Parson/ 22/e, p. 240-241

questions.text: A healthy 25-year-old software engineer participates in a 10-km charity run. Which of the following muscle does this person use during expiration?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the person has performed a strenuous exercise, so he will be using accessory muscles of respiration along with the primary muscle of respiration. Internal intercostals and abdominal recti are the muscles involved.

Reference:Ganong's Revien Of Medical physiology, 28th Edition Page no: 611-616

choices.text: reassure him that there is nothing seriously wrong.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man complains of soreness in the left vestibule over the last 3 to 4 months that has failed to respond to a variety of topical preparations. A small ulcerated area is noted on the inner vestibule skin from which a biopsy is taken. The histology report suggests chronic inflammation, a few basaloid cells, and areas of necrosis. As a consequence, one should
questions.solution:
It may be difficult to obtain representative tissue from this area, particularly if performed under local anesthesia. The presence of necrosis and basaloid cells should suggest the possibility of basal cell carcinoma, and the chronic inflammation and necrosis may simply be from the center of the ulcer. A further deeper biopsy is indicated to exclude malignancy. Imaging of this area is generally unhelpful, and long-term systemic antibiotics are unlikely to alter the situation materially.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 33 Acute and Chronic Nasal Disorders page no 758

choices.text: Decreased levels of von Willebrand factor

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl was brought in because of a nosebleed that will not stop for 1 hour. A physical exam reveals diffuse petechiae and purpura.
Bleeding time: ELEVATED
Prothrombin time: NORMAL
Partial thromboplastin time: NORMAL
Platelet count: 195,000/mm3
The peripheral blood smear shows normal cell morphology. Which of the following characteristics is most likely true about this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with superficial bleeding, an elevated bleeding time, a normal platelet count, and normal platelet morphology on peripheral blood smear most likely has Glanzmann thrombasthenia. This disease is caused by a mutation in glycoprotein IIb/IIIa.

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is caused by a genetic mutation in the platelet aggregation receptor glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. This mutation causes a defect in platelet quality but not in platelet quantity. Like all platelet disorders, it will present with superficial bleeding such as nosebleeds, petechiae, and purpura, which will be accompanied by laboratory testing with a prolonged bleeding time or platelet function analyzer test. Notably, this disorder will have a normal platelet count, prothrombin time, and partial thromboplastin time. Finally, the morphology of the platelets on the peripheral blood smear will be normal in this disease.

Other options:

Option A: Decreased levels of von Willebrand factor is incorrect because this disease would present with an elevated partial thromboplastin time. This occurs because the von Willebrand factor stabilizes coagulation factor VIII.

Option B: Mutation in glycoprotein Ib is incorrect because this is the cause of Bernard-Soulier syndrome, which results in enlarged platelet morphology on a peripheral blood smear.

Option D: Production of anti-platelet antibodies is incorrect because in immune thrombocytopenia the platelet count would be decreased.

Reference:Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department with a painful swollen knee after he had a fall down. His male family members have a similar history of this disease. Which of the sets of results shown would most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient who has easy bruising and experienced hemarthrosis after a ground-level fall most likely has Hemophilia, which will present with an isolated increase in partial thromboplastin time.

Hemophilia is a hereditary deficiency in a coagulation factor that results in increased deep bleeding such as bruising or hemarthrosis. The 2 most common causes of hemophilia are deficiencies of factor VIII, also known as hemophilia A, and factor IX, also known as hemophilia B. Since both of these proteins are in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation, they will present with an increase in partial thromboplastin time (PTT) but no change in prothrombin time (PT). They are inherited in an X-linked recessive manner so they are much more common in males than females.

Other Options:

Option A: Normal PT, PTT, and bleeding time would be seen in normal patients or those who have excessive activation of plasminogen. This patient's presentation is much more consistent with hemophilia.

Option B: An isolated increase in PT would be seen in patients who are taking warfarin or who have a mutation in an extrinsic pathway coagulation factor. Hemophilia is most commonly caused by a mutation in factor VIII or IX, which are intrinsic pathway factors.

Option D: An isolated increase in bleeding time would be seen in patients with platelet disorders; however, these disorders would present with superficial bleeding such as nosebleeds or petechiae rather than deep bleeding.

Reference:Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 441

questions.text: A 37-year-old female has a nodular mass in her neck. FNAC demonstrated malignancy and total thyroidectomy was performed. A histological sample of the excised lesion is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histological sample shows a psammoma body. Psammoma bodies are dystrophic calcified cancer cells seen in papillary thyroid cancer.

Psammoma bodies are a common feature of papillary carcinoma and are also seen in ovarian dysgerminomas and meningiomas. Papillary carcinoma has a papillary architecture with stalks lined by cuboidal epithelium. Other histological features include ground glass nuclei and nuclear grooves. Papillary carcinomas account for 75-90% of thyroid cancers. The prognosis is excellent.

Psamomma bodies are seen in papillary adenocarcinoma of the thyroid, serous papillary cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary, meningioma, and mesothelioma.

Other Options:

Option A: Lymphomas are typically solid tumors of lymphatic cells. Thyroid lymphoma is associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

Option B: Uniform follicles are characteristic of follicular carcinoma.

Option C: Medullary carcinoma originates from parafollicular C cells that produce calcitonin. Histologically, amyloid deposition is a prominent characteristic of medullary carcinoma.

Reference:Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 57

questions.text: A patient's current medications include albuterol, ipratropium bromide, fluoxetine, lisinopril, rosiglitazone, topiramate, lorazepam, and over-the-counter fish oil supplements. The current medications are most likely to increase the patient's risk of which of the following?
questions.solution:
According to the Beers criteria, physicians should avoid prescribing ≥ 3 CNS-active drugs in geriatric patients because combining these drugs can cause sedation, cognitive impairment, and delirium, which can increase the risk of falls and resulting fractures. CNS-active drugs include antidepressants (tricyclic antidepressants, SSRIs, SNRIs), antipsychotics, antiepileptics, benzodiazepines, nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics, and opioids. Elderly patients are especially sensitive to benzodiazepines. This patient's orthostatic presyncope and hearing loss are also risk factors for falls. In addition, there is a higher risk of fractures in this patient, who has risk factors for decreased bone mineral density (e.g., postmenopausal woman, glitazone use).

Polypharmacy is often unavoidable in elderly patients because of the presence of multiple comorbidities but can sometimes occur as a result of a prescription cascade. Polypharmacy is associated with a greater risk of poor patient compliance, medical errors, decreased therapeutic efficacy, and/or adverse drug reactions (due to drug-drug interactions). Strategies to avoid polypharmacy and its complications include adherence to the Beers criteria, medication reconciliation, and periodic medication reviews with the use of drug-interaction checkers.

Reference:Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 28

choices.text: magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and paranasal sinuses
University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman complains of severe loss of sense of smell following a minor traffic accident. She did not suffer any head injury. She is taking legal action against the other driver and has asked for a medical report. Which of the following investigations will be most useful in assessing olfactory damage?
questions.solution:
The University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test is well-validated for sex and age. It will quantify the degree of the loss into normal, hyposmia, or anosmia and will help to exclude the possibility of malingering as a few correct responses will be given by guesswork alone. Thus, a score of zero would be very suspicious of exaggerating the loss. Evoked-response olfactometry can confirm the presence or absence of olfaction but will not quantify it and is difficult to do without trigeminal stimulation. Imaging can be useful to exclude inflammation, infection, or neoplasia but will not demonstrate olfactory damage secondary to trauma. The use of intrathecal fluorescein can be of use in identifying the site of a cerebrospinal fluid leak after a head injury, but this can occur independently of olfactory damage, with which it does not correlate.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 33 Acute and Chronic Nasal Disorders page no 744

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The above-given image is of an MCU done on a patient. The above-given image shows contrast reaching up to the kidneys during micturition which is not seen in normal MCU studies. This is suggestive of VUR. In this case, the contrast reaches up to the kidneys and there is hydronephrosis as well suggestive of grade V VUR.

Grading of VUR

  • grade 1: reflux limited to the ureter
  • grade 2: reflux up to the renal pelvis
  • grade 3: mild dilatation of the ureter and pelvicalyceal system
  • grade 4
    • tortuous ureter with moderate dilatation
    • blunting of fornices but preserved papillary impressions
  • grade 5
    • tortuous ureter with severe dilatation of the ureter and pelvicalyceal system
    • loss of fornices and papillary impressions

Reference:AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1256

questions.text: A male was presented with an 8 mm dark lesion on his back. The lesion has irregular borders and marked internal color variation. Upon excisional biopsy, the presence of which of the following would best estimate the risk of metastasis in this patient's lesion:
questions.solution:
The patient's lesion conforms to the typical presentation of malignant melanoma. Malignant melanomas typically present with asymmetry, border irregularities, color variation, and a diameter greater than 6 mm. However, there are exceptions to this rule.

Malignant melanomas commonly have two growth phases. In the first (or radial) growth phase, the lesion spreads laterally within the epidermis and is not at high risk for metastasis. In the second (or vertical) growth phase, the lesion travels downward into and even beyond the dermis and becomes invasive. Depth of invasion is the most predictive factor for the risk of metastasis and overall prognosis. Breslow's depth and Clark's level are two scales used to describe vertical invasion. Breslow's depth describes the actual depth of invasion, whereas Clark's level refers to the level of anatomical invasion.


The image depicts Breslow's depth and Clark's level for melanoma prognosis.

Other Options:

Option A: Palisading nuclei are a common feature of basal cell carcinomas, which rarely metastasize.

Option B: Keratin pearls are found in squamous cell carcinomas, which rarely metastasize.

Option D: Increased production of melanosomes is not known to be associated with the risk of metastasis in malignant melanoma.

Reference:Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 797

  • Intrapleural pressure is the pressure of the fluid in the thin space between the

visceral and parietal pleura.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of CML presents with progressively worsening dyspnea and a dry cough over the past 2 weeks. On examination, he has slightly increased work of breathing and diffuse rales in the bilateral upper and lower lung fields. CXR shows non-specific alveolar opacities. An endoscopic biopsy of the lung is performed with results shown. This patient's condition is most likely caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette presents with dyspnea and histological findings suggestive of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. This condition is caused by excessive surfactant production or impaired surfactant clearance.

Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is a restrictive lung disorder characterized by an abnormal buildup of pulmonary surfactant in the alveoli. This impairs the ability of the respiratory epithelium to exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide. The two primary causes of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis are (1) excess surfactant production and (2) defective macrophage-mediated clearance of surfactant.

Other Options:

Option A: Antibody-antigen complex deposition is characteristic of a type III hypersensitivity reaction. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (Farmer's lung) is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction in the lung.

Option C: Idiopathic fibroblast proliferation in the lung is suggestive of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. In this condition, persistent idiopathic inflammation results in fibrosis and cyst formation in the lung.

Option D: Idiopathic granulomatous inflammation in multiple organs is characteristic of sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a systemic condition that can affect the lungs in addition to other organ systems.

Reference:Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 495

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of postmortem hanging?
questions.solution:
The absence of a salivary dribble mark is a feature of postmortem hanging. The presence of a salivary dribble is a feature of antemortem hanging.

A salivary dribble mark is the surest sign of an antemortem hanging and is due to the consequence of pressure and friction on the submandibular salivary glands due to the ligature. This results in the dribbling of the saliva from the angle of the mouth (angle opposite to the knot).

The other options are all signs of antemortem hanging.

Option 1 - Oblique ligature mark is seen in antemortem hanging. This is in contrast to the circular ligature mark seen in postmortem hanging.

Option 3 - Le facie sympathique is the term used to describe the phenomenon when the eye on the same side as the ligature mark remains open with a dilated pupil. This is caused by pressure on the cervical sympathetic chain of that side, It is an indicator of

antemortem hanging.

Option 4 - Tear of carotid artery intima, known as the Amussat's sign, is seen with antemortem hanging. These are transverse tears and are most clearly seen in obese victims and posteriorly placed knots. While the absence of this sign doesn't exclude antemortem hanging.

It is never seen in postmortem hanging.


Reference:Review of forensic medicine and toxicology by Gautam Biswas page no 166

questions.text: A kidney biopsy light microscopy shows diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. Electron microscopy shows subepithelial spike and dome deposits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms and urine studies are indicative of nephrotic syndrome. Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and subepithelial spike and dome deposits are features of membranous nephropathy.

Features of nephrotic syndrome include peripheral edema and proteinuria above 3.5 g per day. Membranous glomerulopathy is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in Caucasian adults, whereas minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.

Other Options:

Option A: MCD is characterized by the effacement of the podocytes on electron microscopy.

Option B: Postinfectious glomerulonephritis and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis each result in a glomerulonephritis clinical scenario characterized by hypertension and RBC casts in the urine. These are not necessarily associated with nephrotic-range proteinuria.

Option C: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is characterized by negative immunofluorescence and non-albumin-specific proteinuria.

Reference:Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 549

Inhibition of acetylcholine activity in the basal ganglia

Decreased peripheral conversion of levodopa to dopamine

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with Parkinson's disease is brought up after a syncopal episode. Over the past two weeks, the patient has felt light-headed upon standing and has noticed that his legs have been swollen. He was started on medication for early symptoms of Parkinson's disease one month ago. Examination of the lower extremities shows a lacy, purple rash and 2+ pitting edema. The physician decreases the dose of medication. The patient is most likely experiencing adverse effects caused by a drug that works through which of the following mechanisms of action?
questions.solution:
This patient shows signs of amantadine toxicity, including orthostatic hypotension, livedo reticularis, peripheral edema, and ataxia.

Amantadine increases dopamine release, decreases dopamine reuptake, and inhibits the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor. It can be used as initial short-term monotherapy in patients with mild symptoms of Parkinson's disease, mainly for those with prominent tremors. In addition to the side effects seen in this patient, amantadine is associated with anticholinergic-like side effects (e.g., dry mouth, constipation), prolonged QT interval, and psychological disorders (e.g., hallucinations, anxiety).

Reference:Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 452

choices.text: Coagulation necrosis and marginal contraction band necrosis

questions.text: A patient was seen 7 weeks ago for STEMI and was treated appropriately. Which of the following best describes the cellular changes occurring in this patient's heart currently?
questions.solution:
A myocardial infarction occurs when ischemia leads to necrosis of the cardiac myocytes. The initial damage that occurs to the heart leads to a cascade of cellular changes in the remodeling process. Collagen deposition and scar formation is the ultimate/final part of the remodeling process and typically occurs 2-8 weeks after myocardial infarction.

Since collagen lacks the contractile properties of a myocyte, an aneurysm can occur at the location of the scar. This can present with a hypokinetic or dilation on echocardiography and with ECG changes.

Other Options:

Option A: Coagulation necrosis and marginal contraction band necrosis occur 12-24 hours after myocardial infarction.

Option C: Early coagulation necrosis and edema occur 4-12 hours after a new myocardial infarction.

Option D: Granulation tissue and neovascularization occur 10-14 days after a new myocardial infarction.

Reference:Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 399

questions.text: A drug irreversibly inhibits interferon-gamma receptors on human immunity. Which of the following infections is most likely to occur in patients who take this drug?
questions.solution:
IFN-γ is normally secreted by NK cells and Th1 cells in response to antigen exposure or macrophage-derived IL-12. IFN-γ plays a key role in the activation of macrophages and differentiation into epithelioid cells and giant cells, which are essential for the elimination and control of mycobacterial and other granulomatous infections. Blockade of IFN-γ receptors leads to impaired phagocytosis and impaired granuloma formation, which increases the risk of disseminated mycobacterial infection.

TNF-α plays an important role in the sequestration of Mycobacterium tuberculosis in granulomas. Inhibition of TNF-α results in the breakdown of granulomas and the release of mycobacteria, which can also increase the risk of disseminated mycobacterial infection.


Reference:Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 57

questions.text: An 8-year-old child with delayed development, was referred for evaluation of recurrent infections. History is notable for the Presence of congenital heart defects. Further examination reveals the presence of a cleft palate and blood work reveals the presence of hypocalcemia. Which Component of the immune system is likely to be affected in this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical features point towards the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome. Cell-mediated

Immunity Is affected in DiGeorge syndrome.

DiGeorge syndrome is a complex embryopathy with an autosomal dominant inheritance that is caused by microdeletions in chromosome ZZ, leading to multiple developmental defects (involving the 3rdand 4thpharyngeal pouches), including hypoparathyroidism, and dysmorphic Facies. Children with DiGeorge syndrome are born without a thymus and therefore lack the I-cell component of the cell-mediated immune system. The disease may range from mildly increased susceptibility to infections to a severe disease requiring a thymic or hematopoietic stem cell transplant. Patients are generally able to cope with extracellular bacterial infections because their innate and T cell-independent antibody responses are intact, but they cannot effectively eliminate intracellular pathogens such as viruses, and intracellular bacteria.

The clinical features of this syndrome include Congenital heart disease- aortic arch anomalies Abnormalities of the palate like cleft palate.

Facial dysmorphism such as hypertelorism, antimongoloid slant, low set ears, micrognathia,Short philtrum, bifid uvula.

Thymic hypoplasia with impaired T cell immunity.

Parathyroid hypoplasia results in hypocalcemia (tetany).

Reference :Ananthanarayan and Panikers Textbook of Microbiology Tenth edition pg no 132
