questions.text: A 53-year-old patient presents with fever and cough, with a history of a visit to China and the consumption of pickled crayfish. He now complains of rusty sputum and cough which is suggestive of Paragonimus westermani infection. What is the Infective form of this fluke?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of Paragonimus westermani (oriental lung fluke)

Infection. Metacercariae encysted in crab or crayfish is the infective form.

Paragonimus westermani is a trematode. The transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or Undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The parasite is endemic to Japan, Korea, Taiwan, China, and Southeast Asia. Endemic foci of P westermani are present in Manipur.

Definitive host: Man, and many other crab-eating mammals and domestic animals

The adult worms live in the respiratory tract of the definitive host in cystic spaces surrounded by a fibrous capsule formed by the host tissues. Unembryonated eggs escape into the Bronchi and are coughed up and voided in sputum or swallowed and passed in feces.

Clinical features include cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. There is viscous sputum speckled with golden-brown eggs. Demonstration of the eggs in sputum or feces provides definitive Evidence.

Praziquantel (25 mg/kg TDS for 1-2 days) is the drug of choice

Reference:Ananthanarayan and Panikers Textbook of Microbiology Tenth edition pg no 160

questions.text: An 18 year old girl who was using spectacles for-last 10 years, came with a history of photopsia and sudden loss of vision in the right eye. In order to confirm the diagnosis, which of the following clinical examinations should be performed?
questions.solution:
A patient having a sudden loss of vision and a history of glasses suggestive of high chances of retinal detachment following having a peripheral retinal degeneration-like lattice etc..so a fundus examination is done by indirect ophthalmoscopy.

Classification of Peripheral Retinal Degenerations

Peripheral retinal degenerations are classified according to the following criteria:

  • Location- equatorial, peripheral, or combined
  • Pathomorphology- trophic, tractional, atrophic, or combined
  • Depth of retinal changes- intraretinal, retinal, vitreoretinal, or chorioretinal
  • Risk for retinal detachment
  • Prognosis - progressive or stationary

The following are the commonly used classifications of peripheral retinal degenerations based on the depth of retinal changes observed on optical coherence tomography (OCT):

  • Intra-retinal Degenerations: senile retinoschisis, white-without-pressure, white-with-pressure, dark-without-pressure, peripheral cystoid degeneration, snowflake degeneration, and pearl degeneration
  • Vitreoretinal degenerations: lattice degeneration, snail-track degeneration, retinal tufts, and peripheral retinal breaks
  • Chorioretinal degenerations: paving stone degeneration and peripheral retinal drusen Utility of OCT in diagnosis

Optical coherence tomography (OCT) has been shown to greatly benefit the diagnosis of peripheral retinal degenerations by characterizing structural elements. Such detail includes the structure, shape, and depth of retinal degeneration. Peripheral OCT may further aid in differentiation between types of peripheral retinal degeneration as well associated complications including subclinical retinal detachment, retinoschisis, retinal tears, and vitreoretinal adhesions or tractions. Therefore, OCT should be utilized in the initial diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up for peripheral retinal degeneration.

Reference: Yanoff 2/e, p. 318

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the disease?
questions.solution:
Whiff Test

In the whiff test, vaginal discharge is placed on a slide with a 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution. A positive test result is a release of an amine (fishy) odor after the addition of KOH to the discharge. The odor is due to the release of amines such as putrescine, cadaverine, histamine, and trimethylamine.

Bacterial vaginosis is associated with an intense amine odor on this test; however, the whiff test is not highly sensitive or specific for diagnosing this condition. A negative whiff test result is 65%-85% sensitive for candidal infection; as many as 30% of symptomatic candidiasis cases show false-negative results. The whiff test may be positive for Trichomonas vaginitis.

Reference: Sexually transmitted infection 2ndedition Pg 625

questions.text: Upon performing elbow surgery, the surgeon notes the following as shown in the image. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this male?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with arthritis due to alkaptonuria (also known as Ochronosis or Ochronotic arthritis) which is due to the deficiency in homogentisate oxidase.

Alkaptonuria is due to the inability to break down homogentisic acid, the breakdown products of tyrosine and phenylalanine metabolism, resulting from a deficiency of homogentisate oxidase. Patients typically have the onset of symptoms before the 3rd decade of life due to the accumulation of homogentisic acid. They will present with arthritis due to accumulation within the cartilage, resulting in a black discoloration of the cartilage. Similarly, the skin and sclera discolor, and the urine discolors upon sitting in open air due to the oxidizing oxygen or upon the addition of an oxidizing agent to the urine.

The image shows the discoloration of the cartilage due to the deposition of homogentisic acid.

Other Options:

Option A: Phenylalanine hydroxylase is deficient in phenylketonuria.

Option B: Branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase is deficient in maple syrup disease.

Option D: Cystathionine synthase is deficient in homocystinuria.

Reference:Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 310

questions.text: Which of the following is protective in a jaundiced newborn?
questions.solution:
Administration of phenobarbital induces glucuronyl transferase, thus reducing neonatal jaundice. Sepsis and acidosis increase the risk of neurologic damage by increasing the blood-brain barrier's permeability to bilirubin. Hypoalbuminemia reduces the infant's ability to transport unconjugated bilirubin to the liver, and similarly drugs that displace bilirubin from albumin elevate free levels of unconjugated bilirubin in the serum.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady delivered a healthy baby at 37 weeks of gestation. She was a known case of chronic hepatitis B infection. She was positive for HBsAg but negative for HBeAg. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for the baby?
questions.solution:
Perinatal transmission of hepatitis B

The likelihood of perinatal transmission of HBV correlates with the presence of HBeAg. 90% of HBeAg-positive end only 10 to 15% of anti-HBe-positive mothers transmit infection.

Most infections are transmitted at the time of delivery.

Acute infection in neonates is clinically asymptomatic but the child is likely to become an HBsAg carrier and has a high risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma.

Treatment of perinatal exposure:

For all infants born to HBsAg-positive mothers:

A single dose of HBIG Should be given intramuscularly In the Thigh soon after birth followed by a complete course of three injections of recombinant hepatitis B vaccine with the first dose to be given within the first 12 hours of life.A subsequent dose of active immunization should be given after one month and six months.

questions.text: A 19-year-old football player was tackling his opponent when his finger got stuck in his opponent's t-shirt. He later presented with the following deformity. The given deformity in the finger results as a damage to which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
• The image below shows a Jersey finger. Jersey Finger is a traumatic flexor tendon injury caused by an avulsion injury of the FDP from the insertion at the base of the distal phalanx.
  • Diagnosis is made clinically with a finger that lies in slight extension at the DIP relative to other fingers in the resting position. Radiographs may show a bony avulsion if present.
  • Treatment is usually direct tendon repair or open reduction and internal fixation depending on the presence and size of a bony avulsion.

Flexor digitorum superficialis is attached to the PIP and causes its flexion.

Lumbricals are inserted on the dorsal digital expansion and are responsible for flexion at the MCP joint and extension at IP joint Palmar interossei also insert on the dorsal digital expansion and causes adduction of fingers and flexion at the MCP joint.

Citrulline + aspartate + ATP --> arginosuccinate + AMP + PPi

questions.text: Which of the following reactions is the rate-limiting step in the Urea cycle?
questions.solution:
The reaction NH3 + HCO3- + 2 ATP --> carbamoyl phosphate + 2 ADP + Pi is the rate-limiting step in the urea cycle, which is catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I and activated by N-acetyl glutamate.

The purpose of the urea cycle is to degrade excess amino acids and safely remove nitrogenous waste from the body. The cycle begins by synthesizing carbamoyl phosphate from ammonia, bicarbonate ion, and ATP by the enzyme, carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I, the rate-limiting step in the reaction. This reaction requires N-acetyl glutamate which regulates the cycle and is only produced when excess amino acids are present. The overall reaction, occurring both in the cytosol and mitochondria, converts two amino groups from ammonia as mentioned above and one from aspartate to urea.

Reference:Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 272

questions.text: 12 years male came with swelling of the upper-end tibia. his x-ray image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Brodie's Abscess: Seen in Immunocompetent Host!

  • It is a long-standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone (long-standing because of the strong defense mechanism of the body).
  • The patient is usually between 11 to 20 years of age. Common sites are the upper end of the tibia and the lower end of the femur. It is usually located at the metaphysis.
  • A deep boring pain is the predominant symptom that may become worse at night. In some instances,it becomes worse on walking and is relieved by rest.
  • Classical Brodie's abscess looks like a small walled-off lytic cavity ( with Sclerotic margins) in bone with little or no periosteal reaction.
  • Usual isolated organism is Staphylococcus aureus (although most cultures are negative)
  • Treatment is by operation. Surgical evacuation and curettage are performed under antibiotic cover. If the cavity is large, it is packed with cancellous bone chips.

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5thedition page no 175.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman had a history of allergies and asthma. She comes in the OPD complaining of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge, and bilateral nasal blockage for one year. On examination, multiple polyps with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions are seen in nasal cavities. Biopsy was taken and the material on culture showed many hyphae with dichotomous branching typically at 45°. Which of the following is the most likely organism responsible?
questions.solution:
A fungi with septate hyphae in an asthmatic patient can be none other than aspergillus, and this is a case of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

Allergic Bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is seen in an atopic individual with elevated IgE levels following sensitization to inhaled aspergillus spores

In bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, fungus grows within the lumen of bronchioles, which may be occluded. The condition gets worsened after the development of hypersensitivity to the fungus.

Diagnosis is made by an elevated IgE, a positive skin prick test to A. Fumigatus or detection of aspergillus-specific IgE and IgG. Central bronchiectasis is characteristic

Aspergillus hyphae are hyaline, narrow, and septate with branching at 45°; No yeast forms are present in infected tissue. Hyphae can be seen in cytology or microscopy preparation.

Reference:Ananthanarayan and Panikers Textbook of Microbiology Tenth edition

questions.text: A 38-year-old male, Siddharth presents with 8 months of uncontrollable anxiety. He states that he experiences overwhelming anxiety and worry in performing just ordinary tasks of daily living. He is started on Venlafaxine. Which of the following is a potential side effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
Venlafaxine is a Serotonin Norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). Side effects of SNRIs most commonly include increased blood pressure and stimulant effects.

Venlafaxine and Duloxetine are the two most commonly encountered SNRIs. SNRIs are used in the treatment of depression, generalized anxiety disorder (venlafaxine), and diabetic peripheral neuropathy (duloxetine).

The stimulant side effects of these medications (including hypertension) are due to increased levels of norepinephrine. Additional side effects include sedation and nausea.

Reference:Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 481

questions.text: While performing an autopsy on a burn victim, the following cutaneous findings were noted. What is the term used to describe these burns?
questions.solution:
The term used to describe the burns shown in the image is filigree burn or arborescent burn or Lichtenberg's flower or feathering. It is a finding in burns due to lightning.

The fern-like pattern of erythema in the skin indicates the path taken by the electrical discharge. It usually occurs over the shoulder or the flanks within an hour of the injury and disappears in a day or two. It occurs due to the rupture of small vessels and is seen in a fern-like pattern or the branching of a tree.

Option A: The crocodile skin effect is caused by high-tension current burns, where the voltage is in the multi-kilovolt range, and sparking may occur over many centimeters. This can cause multiple spark lesions giving rise to a crocodile-skin effect.

Option B: When the skin is in firm contact with an electrical conductor, splitting of the layers of the epidermis or those of the epidermal-dermal junction. This may in turn produce a raised blister known as a Joule burn.

The image below shows a Joule burn:


Option C: When the contact is less firm, an air gap is formed between the skin and the conductor. Thus the current traverses the gap as a spark. This leads to a distinct hard brownish keratin nodule raised above the surrounding surface known as a spark lesion.

The image below shows multiple spark lesions and the inset shows the crocodile skin effect:


Image showing electrical marks

questions.text: A young female patient with a recent travel history comes to the OPD with a History of prolonged abdominal pain, diarrhea, and fever gradually increasing in a step ladder pattern. On examination, faint, salmon-colored macules are seen on the trunk. A serological test is used to confirm the diagnosis. This test is an Example of
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of enteric fever/ typhoid fever. The widal test is an Agglutination test done in case of typhoid fever.

Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella. The clinical course may vary from mild undifferentiated pyrexia to a rapidly fatal disease. Clinical manifestations include malaise, step ladder pyrexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and myalgia. Hepatosplenomegaly is a common finding on examination. Rose spots are small erythematous maculopapular lesions that are seen on the chest and abdomen that fade on pressure. They appear in the second week and are seen

Option b: In tube flocculation test, serial dilutions of the toxin/ toxoid are added to tubes containing a fixed quantity of antitoxin. The amount of toxin or toxoid that flocculates optimally with one unit of the antitoxin is defined as Lf dose. Example: Kahn test for syphilis.

Option C: In slide flocculation test, a drop of each of the antigen and antiserum are placed on the slide and mixed by shaking; the appearance of floccules is taken as positive. Eg. the VDRL test for syphilis

Option d: Ring precipitation test, antigen solution is layered over a column of antiserum in a narrow tube. The precipitate is formed at the junction of the 2 liquids. Example: Ascoli's Thermoprecipitin test for detection of anthrax antigen.

Tube flocculation, slide flocculation, and ring precipitation tests are all types of precipitation tests.

Reference:Ananthanarayan and Panikers Textbook of Microbiology Tenth edition pg no 109

questions.text: You introduce a molecule into the tissue culture dish containing the cell line that binds to a transmembrane protein. As a result, the affected cell initiates a process characterized by karyorrhexis, membrane blebbing, and pyknosis. What was the molecule that you introduced into the culture?
questions.solution:
Apoptosis, the process of organized cell death, involves karyorrhexis, pyknosis, and membrane blebbing. The extrinsic pathway of apoptosis can be initiated by FAS-ligand binding to the transmembrane FAS-receptor.

Apoptosis is programmed cell death. The process requires ATP, and caspase enzymes are intimately involved in cellular degradation. There are two major pathways of apoptosis, the intrinsic pathway and the extrinsic pathway. The intrinsic pathway occurs in response to cell injury, loss of stimulatory growth factors, or DNA damage. Extrinsic apoptosis occurs in response to several external 'death' signals, particularly the FAS-ligand binding the FAS death receptor (CD95). In this pathway, the FAS receptor mediates a cascade of caspase activation via FADD, a death domain-containing adapter protein.

Other Options:

Options A & B: Perforin and granzyme B are involved in the apoptosis pathway which is mediated by killer CD8 T cells. Perforin and granzyme B act by damaging the cell membrane, not by binding to a transmembrane receptor.

Option D: A decrease in growth factors (e.g., IL-2 for proliferating immune cells) can lead to the induction of the intrinsic apoptosis pathway.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 31

questions.text: patient presents with painful and enlarged thyroid, with symptoms suggestive of hyperthyroidism. She experiences throat pain along with jaw pain. Treatment of choice is?
questions.solution:
The patient with subacute thyroiditis usually presents with a painful and enlarged thyroid, sometimes accompanied by a fever. There may be features of thyrotoxicosis or hypothyroidism, depending on the phase of the illness. Malaise and symptoms of an upper respiratory tract infection may precede the thyroid-related features by several weeks. In other patients, the onset is acute, severe, and without obvious antecedent. The patient typically complains of a sore throat, and examination reveals a small goiter that is exquisitely tender. Pain is often referred to as the jaw or ear. Complete resolution is the usual outcome, but late-onset permanent hypothyroidism occurs in 15% of cases, particularly in those with coincidental thyroid autoimmunity. A prolonged course over many months, with one or more relapses, occurs in a small percentage of patients

Relatively large doses of aspirin (e.g., 600 mg every 4-6 h) or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are sufficient to control symptoms in many cases. If this treatment is inadequate, or if the patient has marked local or systemic symptoms, glucocorticoids should be given. The usual starting dose is 15-40 mg of prednisone, depending on severity. The dose is gradually tapered over 6-8 weeks, in response to the improvement in symptoms and the ESR. If a relapse occurs during glucocorticoid withdrawal, the dosage should be increased and then withdrawn more gradually. Thyroid function should be monitored every 2-4 weeks using TSH and unbound T4 levels. Symptoms of thyrotoxicosis improve spontaneously but may be ameliorated by β-adrenergic blockers; antithyroid drugs play no role in the treatment of the thyrotoxic phase. Levothyroxine replacement may be needed if the hypothyroid phase is prolonged, but doses should be low enough (50-100 μg daily) to allow TSH-mediated recovery

Reference:Jameson J, Fauci AS, Kasper DL, Hauser SL, Longo DL, Loscalzo J. eds. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20e New York, NY: McGraw-Hill: Page 2708.

questions.text: The CHARGE association is most commonly encountered in relation to which congenital head and neck anomaly?
questions.solution:
The CHARGE association is a nonrandom pattern of congenital anomalies that occurs with choanal atresia. Additional anomalies include coloboma, congenital heart disease, retarded growth and development, ear abnormalities, and deafness. Responses C, and D, although congenital anomalies are not encountered with this disorder. Cleft palate has not been specifically reported with the CHARGE association.

Reference: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 46 CONGENITAL ANOMALIES OF THE HEAD AND NECK page no 1079

questions.text: You are a final-year student on COVID-19 ward duty. After finishing your shift, you carry out the doffing according to the guidelines. The last item you remove is the following. Which bind do you discard it in?
questions.solution:
All used masks, head cover, shoe cover, disposable linen, anatomical waste, soiled waste, discarded medicines, and non-plastic overalls are discarded in a yellow bag. These bags are labeled as COVID-19 bags and are kept double-layered.


Reference: Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 883

questions.text: A 21-year-old man injured his left shoulder while playing team sports. Now, he has pain in the left shoulder and is unable to move his arm. A radiograph of the shoulder was done, as given below. Which lesion does it depict?
questions.solution:
Above diagram shows the effect in the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head, i.e Hill-Sachs lesion.

Hill-Sachs lesion: A posterolateral head defect is caused by an impression fracture on the glenoid rim; this is seen in 27% of acute anterior dislocations and 74% of recurrent anterior dislocations

These are impaction fractures produced as a result of anterior dislocation of the shoulder and the humeral head is impacted against the rim of the glenoid at the time of dislocation


Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion is seen in case of posterior dislocation of the shoulder here, the defect is on the anteromedial aspect of the humeral head

Bankart lesion occurs in anterior dislocation of shoulder where the dislocated head tears not only the fibrocartilaginous labrum from almost the anterior half of the din of the glenoid but 280 the capsule and periosteum from the anterior surface of the neck of the scapula. If there occurs a fracture of the anterior part of genoid it is called the bony Bankart lesson Image x-ray image shows a bony Banker and Hill-Sachs lesion

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 5thedition page no 90

questions.text: A girl comes to you with complaints of swelling bilaterally in the groin, initially suspected to be an inguinal hernia. Sonography has revealed it to be bilateral testes in the inguinal canal. Which of the following is the expected karyotype of the child?
questions.solution:
• Bilateral testes in the inguinal canal in a child raised as female (phenotypic females) is suggestive of androgen insensitivity syndrome.
  • It is X-linked recessive, caused by mutations in the androgen receptor gene making the receptor insensitive to androgens. Karyotype is 46-XY (Genetic male)
  • Patients are phenotypically female because a part of testosterone is converted to estrogen, which causes the development of female external genitalia, normal development of breast, and female habitus.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20thed., pg. 2757

questions.text: Suresh, a 45-year-old male, accidentally consumed 25 tablets of Dabigatran (Direct Thrombin Inhibitors). Which of the following drug is used as an antidote for the reversal of a Dabigatran overdose?
questions.solution:
Idarucizumab is a specific reversal agent for dabigatran. It is a humanized monoclonal antibody fragment (Fab) that binds to Dabigatran and its acyl glucuronide metabolites with higher affinity than the binding affinity of dabigatran to thrombin, neutralizing their anticoagulant effect.

In October 2015, the FDA approved Idarucizumab as the first specific reversal agent for Dabigatran, indicated for patients with life-threatening or uncontrolled bleeding, as well as in cases where rapid reversal is needed for urgent and emergent procedures.

Reference:Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 659

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was admitted Days after a crush injury to his right eye following a road traffic accident. He had been treated by a local village quack. On examination, the wound which was Bandaged with gauze, appeared to be heavily contaminated with soil, the local Muscles appeared to have been crushed, there was edema and pain at the site and Crepitus was felt on palpation. Which of the following is false about the suspected Causative agent?
questions.solution:
The suspected causative agent based on clinical presentation (which indicates Features of gas-gangrene) is C. perfringens (the most common cause of gas-gangrene). It is a capsulated, non-motile, gram-positive Bacillus. Alpha-toxin is the principal virulence Factor. It has both phospholipase C and Sphingomyelinase activities

Reference:Ananthanarayan and Panikers Textbook of Microbiology third edition pg no 508

questions.text: A 37-week-gestation male is born after an uncomplicated pregnancy to a 33-year-old mother. At birth, he was lethargic and had an HR of 40. Oxygen was administered via bag and mask, and he was intubated; his HR remained at 40 bpm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
• If the HR is still less than 60 bpm despite PPV with 100% oxygen, then chest compressions are given for 30 seconds. If the HR is still less than 60 bpm, then drug therapy (usually epinephrine) is indicated.

(Ref. Neonatal resuscitation program, AAP, 2018)

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory changes would you expect to see in a patient with Diabetic Ketoacidosis?
questions.solution:
Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), is characterized by elevated ketone bodies with an elevated β-hydroxybutyrate: acetoacetate ratio.

DKA is a manifestation of untreated type I diabetes mellitus (DM) that results from an absolute insulin deficiency and a surge in counter-regulatory hormones (e.g., glucagon, growth hormone, and catecholamines). This leads to a dramatic elevation in serum glucose and an anion gap metabolic acidosis due to ketone buildup. Clinically, DKA may present with vomiting, abdominal pain, a fruity odor to the breath (due to ketonemia), and severe dehydration. β-hydroxybutyrate and acetoacetate are the 2 ketone bodies that are elevated in DKA. Their equilibrium is represented by the following equation:

β-hydroxybutyrate + NAD+ <-> acetoacetate + NADH

DKA will increase the NADH: NAD+ ratio, which shifts the equilibrium from acetoacetate to β-hydroxybutyrate. This leads to an increase in both ketones with a concomitant increase in the β-hydroxybutyrate: acetoacetate ratio.

Source:

Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 213

questions.text: Your patient is a 75-year-old man with an indwelling urinary catheter following prostatectomy for prostate cancer. He now has a sudden onset of fever of 40°C, blood pressure of 70/40, and a pulse of 140. You draw several blood cultures, and the laboratory reports that all are positive for a gram-negative rod that forms red-pigmented colonies. Which one of the following bacteria is the most likely cause of this infection?
questions.solution:
Serratia infections are clearly related to Hospitalization, especially to invasive Procedures such as intravenous catheterization, Respiratory intubation, and urinary tract Manipulations. In addition, outbreaks of Serratia pneumonia have been associated With contamination of the water in respiratory Therapy devices. Prior to the extensive use Of these procedures, S. marcescens was a Harmless organism most frequently isolated From environmental sources such as water, Serratia also causes endocarditis in users of injection drugs As with many other Gram-negative rods, the pathogenesis of septic.

The shock caused by these organisms is related to The endotoxins in their cell walls. S. marcescens Produces red-pigmented colonies.

The pigment which is red in color is known as Prodigiosin.

Reference :

Ananthanarayan and Panikers Textbook of Microbiology 3rd edition pg no 615

choices.text: Regulates calcium entry into the sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: Which among the following is the function of phospholamban?
questions.solution:
• Phospholamban is a protein that regulates SR Ca2+ ATPase (SERCA) in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. When phosphorylated, phospholamban stimulates the Ca2+ ATPase, resulting in greater uptake and storage of Ca2+ by the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  • Increased Ca2+ uptake by the sarcoplasmic reticulum has two effects:
  • It causes faster relaxation (i.e., briefer contraction).

it increases the amount of stored Ca2+ for release on subsequent beats.

  • Phosphorylation of phospholamban is responsible for the positive inotropic effect on the myocardium observed after the stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system.
  • This effect is mediated via activation of 1 receptor, which are coupled via a Gs protein to adenylyl cyclase.
  • This positive inotropic effect has three important features: increased peak tension, increased rate of tension development, and fastor rate of relaxation. Faster relaxation means that the contraction (twitch) is shorter, allowing more time for refilling.

Physiology, E-Book (Costanzo Physiology)

5th Edition, Pg 142

questions.text: The following finding on a physical examination was noted on a 43-year-old gentleman who presented for the evaluation of suspected URTI. All of the following conditions are associated with this finding except
questions.solution:
The finding shown in Figure is characteristic of clubbing.

Clubbing occurs in the distal portions of the digits and is characterized by the widening of the fingertips, the convexity of the nail contour, and the loss of the normal 15-degree angle between the proximal nail and cuticle. Clinically, it can be sometimes difficult to ascertain whether clubbing is present. One approach to the diagnosis of clubbing is to measure the diameter of the finger at the base of the nail and at the tip of the finger in all 10 fingers. For each finger, a ratio between the base of the nail and the tip of the finger is determined. If the sum of all 10 fingers is greater than 1, then clubbing is felt to be present. A simpler approach is to have an individual place the dorsal surfaces of the distal fourth digits from each hand together. In a normal individual, there should be a diamond-shaped space between the digits. When an individual has clubbing, this space is obliterated. Clubbing most commonly occurs in advanced lung disease, especially bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis, and interstitial lung diseases like sarcoidosis or idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Clubbing was originally described in individuals with empyema and can occur in chronic lung infections, including lung abscesses, tuberculosis, or fungal infections.

Pulmonary vascular lesions and lung cancer also are associated with clubbing. However, the chronic obstructive pulmonary disease does not cause clubbing. However, the causes of clubbing are not limited to the pulmonary system alone. Clubbing can be a benign familial condition and is also associated with a variety of other disorders, including cyanotic congenital heart disease, subacute bacterial endocarditis, Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, celiac disease, and cancer of the esophagus, liver, small bowel, and large bowel. In untreated hyperthyroidism, clubbing can occur in association with periostitis in a condition called thyroid acropachy. Although these numerous clinical associations have been described for many centuries, the cause of clubbing remains unknown.

( Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition, chapter 367)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of induction of labor?
questions.solution:
Induction of labor means stimulation of contractions before the spontaneous onset of labor.

Prematurity alone is never the indication for induction of labor, rather it is a contraindication of IOL.

In prematurity, we try to prolong the pregnancy as much as we can by giving tocolytics.

Common indications for induction of Labor-

  1. Preeclampsia
  2. Maternal medical complications: diabetes mellitus, chronic renal disease, cholestasis of pregnancy
  3. Post-term pregnancy
  4. Antepartum hemorrhage
  5. IUGR with doppler changes
  6. Rh isoimmunization
  7. IUFD
  8. Fetus with major congenital anomaly

Ref: Dutta's obstetrics 8th edition

Page no 598, 599

questions.text: Which of the following lingual papillae does not contain taste buds?
questions.solution:
On average, humans have ~ 9 large circumvallate (also termed vallate; L. vallum = rampart surrounded by a moat) papillae across the junction of the anterior two-thirds and the posterior third of the tongue. Each papilla contains, on average, ~ 250 taste buds, although large individual differences are present. The foliate (L. folium = leaf) papillae, which consist of ridges between adjacent folds along the posterior part of the margin of the tongue, number less than a dozen on each side. Although estimates vary, the average number of taste buds per foliate papilla is probably around 100 in adults. Fungiform (L. fungi = mushroom) papillae, located over the surface of the anterior part of the tongue, vary considerably in size and shape, some being short and cuboidal and others tall with mushroom-like heads. The typical adult tongue contains several hundred fungiform papillae, although not all harbor taste buds. Of individual fungiform papillae that do contain taste buds, the number of buds ranges from 1 to 18 on those located on the tongue tip and 1 to 9 on those located mid-lingually. The filiform (L. filum = thread) papillae are the most numerous papillae on the tongue but do not harbor taste buds.

Ref: Ballenger's otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery 16th edition chapter no 27 Olfaction and Gustation page no 577

questions.text: IDENTIFY TEST SHOWN IN IMAGE?
questions.solution:
Galeazzi test - The Galeazzi test, sometimes called Allis sign or Skyline test, is used to assess for hip dislocation, specifically testing for developmental dysplasia of the hip.

The test is performed with the infant supine, hips flexed to 45 and knees flexed to 90 with feet flat on the examining surface. The examiner looks for symmetry in the level of the knees. Inequality in the height of the knees is a positive Galeazzi sign and usually is caused by hip dislocation or congenital femoral shortening.

Barlow and Ortolani are done to assess whether the hip is dislocated or reducible respectively.

The Trendelenburg test is done to assess the integrity of the abductor mechanism of the hip joint.

Knee:

Pivot shift test -Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury

Anterior drawer's test -ACL injury

Lachmann's test -ACL injury

Posterior drawer's test -PCL injury

Mc Murray's test -Meniscus injury

Apley's grinding test -Meniscal injury

Adduction & abduction tests - Medial & lateral collateral ligament

Ref. Maheshwari ortho 5th edition page no 22

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient with a CD4 count of 110/pL who is not taking any medications Presents to an emergency department with Complaints of a headache for the past week. He also notes nausea and intermittent Blurred vision. Examination is notable for Normal vital signs without fever but mild Papilledema. Head CT does not show dilated Ventricles. The definitive diagnostic test for this patient is:
questions.solution:
Cryptococcal meningoencephalitis presents With early manifestations of headache, nausea, Gait disturbance, confusion, and visual changes. Fever and nuchal rigidity are often mild or Absent. Papilledema is present in more than 30% of cases. Asymmetric cranial nerve palsies occur in 25% of cases. Neuroimaging findings are often normal. If there are focal neurologic Findings, magnetic resonance imaging may Be used to diagnose cryptococcomas in the Basal ganglia or caudate nucleus, although They are more common in immunocompetent Patients with Cryptococcus neoformans var. Gattii. Imaging does not make the diagnosis The definitive diagnosis remains cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) culture. However, capsular antigen testing In both the serum and the CSF is very sensitive And can provide a presumptive diagnosis.

Reference :

Ananthanarayan and Panikers Textbook of Microbiology 3rd edition

questions.text: A patient suspected to have COVID-19 pneumonia underwent an HRCT examination. What should be the expected finding in this patient on HRCT?
questions.solution:
Several chest CT findings have been reported in more than 70% of RT-PCR test-proven COVID-19 cases, including ground-glass opacities, vascular enlargement, bilateral abnormalities, lower lobe involvement, and posterior predilection. In COVID-19 endemic regions, the observation of these chest CT findings should raise the suspicion of possible COVID-19 diagnosis

Reference: Chest CT in COVID-19: What the Radiologist Needs to Know Thomas C. Kwee and Robert M. Kwee RadioGraphics 2020 40:7, 1848-1865

questions.text: What is the most common manifestation of Neisseria meningitides infection?
questions.solution:
Ceftriaxone as a single-dose IM injection is highly (9/26) effective in the eradication or carrier state and can be used at all ages and also in pregnancy. Ciprofloxacin is also highly effective and can be given orally, but it is not recommended in pregnancy and below 18 years of age.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition Page nos 1114 1117 and 1122

questions.text:
A 23-year-old is involved in a road traffic accident. He was brought to the emergency department unconscious and his GCS score was 7/15. Upon admission, he was vitally stable and conscious and his score improved to 9/15. Suddenly, he lost consciousness and became tachypneic. CT revealed the following

Which of the following correctly matches the meningeal space where it occurs and the vessel implicated?
questions.solution:
The vignette above describes lucid interval, which is classically seen in extradural hematoma but is not specific to this pathology.

The CT findings with a convex-shaped, extra-axial bleed are also consistent with Extradural hematoma.

It occurs in the space between the skull and the endosteal layer and bleeding of the middle meningeal artery is implicated.

questions.text: A 61-year-old female with a history of breast cancer currently on chemotherapy is brought by her husband to her oncologist for evaluation of a tremor. She reports that she developed a hand tremor approximately six months ago, prior to the start of her chemotherapy. The tremor is worse at rest and decreases with purposeful movement. Muscle tone is increased in the upper extremities. Gait examination reveals difficulty initiating gait and shortened steps. Which of the following medications is contraindicated in managing this patient's nausea and diarrhea?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette presents with resting tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia suggestive of Parkinson's disease. The use of dopamine antagonists such as metoclopramide is contraindicated in patients with Parkinson's disease due to a risk of exacerbating parkinsonian symptoms.

Metoclopramide is a D2 receptor antagonist that is often used as a prokinetic agent to increase gastric motility to treat diabetic and post-surgical gastroparesis. It is also used to antagonize the area postrema to inhibit vomiting and is used to manage chemotherapy-induced nausea. However, it is contraindicated in patients with Parkinson's disease because dopamine antagonism in patients with low baseline levels of dopamine levels can cause tardive dyskinesia and exacerbate parkinsonian effects.

Source:

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 705

questions.text: Which of the following national health programs aims at safe water supply to rural areas?
questions.solution:
In order to give momentum to the drinking water supply program, the Government of India created a separate Department of Drinking Water Supply in 1999. In this context, the Ministry of Rural Development launched Sector Reform initiatives.

The 'Swajaldhara' program is an extension of these reform initiatives. According to the government, it is a very powerful step forward to provide drinking water to all water-scarce villages in the shortest possible time and at the least cost.

The key elements of this Scheme are that the rural people should feel the ownership and, therefore, contribute at least 10% of the capital expenditure of the Scheme upfront; and the communities and their Gram Panchayats must shoulder the Operation and Maintenance (O&M) responsibility of the Schemes.

The Ujjwala scheme aims to promote safe fuels among vulnerable populations

Nirmal Bharat Abhiyan aims for sanitation measures

Swacch Bharat Abhiyan aims to eradicate open defecation, among other sanitation measures.

Source:

Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 464

That the patient is in a window period

questions.text: The presence of antibodies against SARS CoV 2 in the blood likely indicates
questions.solution:
The presence of antibodies against SARS-COV 2 in the blood likely indicates a previous infection even if the patient has been asymptomatic.

Antibodies most commonly become detectable 1-3 weeks after symptom onset, at which time evidence suggests that infectiousness likely is greatly decreased and that some degree of Immunity from future infection has developed. But it is imperative to note that the information on SARS CoV 2 is still emerging.

Reference

Online Resource https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hep/testing-overview

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for cesarean section in women with heart disease?
questions.solution:
Cesarean delivery indications in women with Heart Disease-

  1. Dilated aortic root > 4 cm or aortic aneurysm
  2. Acute severe congestive heart failure
  3. Recent myocardial infarction
  4. Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis
  5. Need for emergency valve replacement immediately after delivery
  6. Warfarin administration within 2 weeks of delivery due to fetal risk for intracerebral hemorrhage because the fetal liver takes 2 weeks to metabolize warfarin

Ref: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

Cardiovascular disorders

Page no 920

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient was operated on for an open incisional hernia. The patient developed a surgical site infection on postoperative day 4 and had seropurulent discharge from the suture line. Culture and sensitivity report isolated staphylococcus strains from the infected site. Which among the following antibiotics is effective in this patient per orally?
questions.solution:
Staphylococci

Staphylococci form clumps and are Gram-positive. Staphylococcus aureus is the most important pathogen in this group and is found in the nasopharynx of up to 15% of the population. It can cause suppuration in wounds and around implanted prostheses. Some strains are resistant to many common antibiotics (especially methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, MRSA) and so are difficult to treat. MRSA can be found in the nose of asymptomatic carriers amongst both patients and hospital workers, a potential source of infection after surgery. In parts of northern Europe, the prevalence of MRSA infections has been kept at very low levels using search and destroy methods, which use screening techniques to look for MRSA inpatients before they come into the hospital for elective surgery so that any carriers can be treated before their admission for surgery. Local policies on the management of MRSA depend on the prevalence of MRSA, the type of hospital, the clinical specialty, and the availability of facilities. Widespread swabbing, ward closures, isolation of patients, and disinfection of wards by deep cleaning all have to be carefully considered.

Staphylococcal infections are usually suppurative and localized. Most hospital Staphylococcus aureus strains are now b-lactamase producers and so are resistant to penicillin, but many strains remain sensitive to flucloxacillin, vancomycin, aminoglycosides, and some cephalosporins. There are several novel and innovative antibiotics becoming available that have high activity against resistant strains. Some have the advantage of good oral activity (linezolid), some have a wide spectrum (teicoplanin), and some have good activity in bacteremia (daptomycin) but all are relatively expensive, and some have side effects involving marrow, hepatic and renal toxicity. Their use is justified but needs to be controlled by tight local policies and guidelines that involve clinical microbiologists.

Staphylococcus epidermidis (previously Staphylococcus albus), also known as coagulase-negative staphylococcus, was regarded as a non-pathogenic commensal organism commonly found on the skin but is now recognized as a major threat in vascular and orthopaedic prosthetic surgery and in indwelling vascular cannulas/catheters. The bacteria form biofilms that adhere to prosthetic surfaces and limit the effectiveness of antibiotics.

Reference: love and bailey 27th edition page 44

questions.text: A 50-year-old man suffered a myocardial infarction. Angiography revealed stenosis of 90% in the right coronary artery. Which of the following parts of the conducting system of the heart will be spared?
questions.solution:
The conducting system of the heart is entirely supplied by RCA, except Right Bundle Branch.

SAN is supplied by the SA nodal branch

Septal branch of PIVA supplies the AVN

Bundle of his and LBB is supplied by PIVA

RBB is supplied by left coronary artery

Source- BD Chaurasia's human anatomy, regional and applied, 8th edition, volume-1 page 283

questions.text: A 30-day-old neonate was presented with a history of photophobia and excessive lacrimation. On examination, both the lacrimal duct systems are normal, but there was a large cornea with haziness. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Disease Entity

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG) is a rare disease due to genetically-determined abnormalities in the trabecular meshwork and anterior chamber angle resulting in elevated intraocular pressure (IOP), without other ocular or systemic developmental anomalies. Other terms have been used previously to describe this entity, including trabeculodysgenesis, goniodysgenesis, and primary infantile glaucoma, however, the term PCG replaces these in the 2013 International Classification of Childhood Glaucoma.[2] There are three variants based on the age of presentation as follows:

A Newborn onset (0-1 month)

B infantile-onset (>1-24 months)

C late-onset or late-recognized (>24 months)

D spontaneously arrested cases (very rare, classic findings of eye stretching including Haab striae with normal IOP; must follow as glaucoma suspects nonetheless)

PCG commonly presents between the ages of 3-9 months, but the most severe form is the newborn onset. Elevated IOP is associated with the classic 'triad' of symptoms (photophobia, epiphora, and blepharospasm), which occurs due to rapid expansion of the child's eye causing buphthalmos (Greek = 'ox eye'), corneal enlargement, horizontal or oblique breaks in Descemet membrane (Haab striae) and subsequent corneal edema and opacification. If Haab striae and buphthalmos are seen without elevated IOP, optic nerve cupping, or corneal edema, then the patient has spontaneously arrested PCG. [2]

The prognosis for children with PCG is quite variable, with some achieving the good vision, while others go blind. While PCG accounts for less than 0.01% of all patients with eye diseases, it has been blamed for 5% of childhood blindness worldwide.[3] Vision loss is secondary to corneal scarring or optic nerve damage, and often amblyopia in asymmetric or unilateral cases. Surgical management is the primary treatment modality. If IOP is controlled, vision in the better eye ultimately can be 20/60 or better.[4][5]

Disease Overview and Definition

PCG is the most common form of primary childhood glaucoma and is one, of two primary childhood glaucomas, that presents in children younger than 4 years of age (the other primary childhood glaucoma being juvenile open-angle glaucoma). PCG and other childhood glaucomas presenting in infancy may present with one or more of the classic triad of epiphora, photophobia, and blepharospasm; however, if ocular or systemic abnormalities, either congenital or acquired, are also present, then PCG can be ruled out, and secondary childhood glaucomas need to be considered (i.e. Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome, aniridia, Peters anomaly, persistent fetal vasculature, oculodermal melanocytosis, posterior polymorphous dystrophy, microphthalmos, microcornea, ectopia lentis, Sturge-Weber syndrome, Lowe syndrome, neurofibromatosis, trauma, inflammation, steroid-induced, tumors, retinopathy of prematurity, glaucoma following cataract surgery).

Due to the elasticity of the eye in young children, the 2013 International Classification System for Childhood Glaucoma defined childhood glaucoma as irreversible or reversible damage to the whole eye (not just the optic nerve as glaucoma is defined for adults). Thus, additional important clinical signs in PCG, besides elevated IOP and optic nerve cupping, are corneal enlargement and clouding, Haab striae, and buphthalmos. Not all signs are always present, however, and other parts of the eye also stretch with elevated IOP. Diagnosis of PCG can be delayed if corneas remain clear, despite being enlarged, and bilateral PCG can be missed if signs and symptoms are mild in one eye. Irreversible vision loss results if elevated IOP is untreated or uncontrolled in PCG. Optic nerve damage occurs, and focal corneal edema overlying Haab striae, which can be single or multiple, can lead to permanent corneal scarring and opacification. This corneal scarring can obscure the visual axis or cause astigmatism with or without refractive amblyopia. Amblyopia may also develop due to optic nerve damage, anisometropia, strabismus, or a combination.

Symptoms

Patients with PCG experience one or more of the 'clinical triad' of symptoms including epiphora, photophobia, and blepharospasm. This triad of symptoms is classically associated with PCG due to the corneal edema that results from the elevated IOP and causes irritation. Reduced vision can also occur from corneal edema/opacification or progressive myopia and/or astigmatism. Amblyopia can further worsen vision.

Signs

The main clinical signs of PCG include elevated IOP >21 mmHg, corneal edema and/or enlargement of the eye with buphthalmos, and Haab striae. The IOP at presentation is usually between 30-40 mmHg, though it can be outside this range. [39] IOP in the low-20s mmHg is acceptable if the optic nerve is healthy and the patient's eye growth is within normal limits, but may not be if there are other more severe signs of PCG.

With IOP in the 30-40s mmHg, the cornea becomes cloudy due to diffuse and/or focal edema. As in adult eyes, the endothelial cell layer cannot pump fluid out of the cornea in an eye with elevated IOP. In young children however, there is the additional insult of corneal stretching from the high IOP causing not only enlargement of the cornea, but Descemet breaks, leading to 'striae,' which are areas of bare stroma bordered by two separated edges of Descemet membrane that become ridges due to deposition of hyaline.[8] These are called Haab striae and are associated with acute overlying focal corneal edema when the IOP is high. They occur in about 25% of PCG eyes presenting at birth, and more than 60% of PCG eyes are identified at 6 months of age.[40] There may be single or multiple and are oriented horizontally or obliquely. After normalization of IOP, corneal edema may clear; however, Haab striae remain and may be associated with corneal scarring. The poorly controlled cases of PCG may end up with dense stromal opacification even after IOP is controlled.

A newborn's cornea is typically 9.5-10.5 mm in diameter and increases to 10.0-11.5 mm by age 1.[41] Any diameter above 12.0 mm before 1 year of age suggests an abnormality, especially if there is an asymmetry between the two eyes. If the diameter is greater than 13 mm at any age, glaucoma suspicion should be high. Along with corneal stretching in the setting of elevated IOP, there is stretching of the scleral wall and all tissues within the eye leading to buphthalmos. Corneal enlargement stops around age 3 years, while the sclera can continue to stretch up to age 10 years of age.[8]

Other signs related to eye distension include abnormally deep anterior chamber, myopia (mainly due to elongation and enlargement of the eye), astigmatism (from Haab striae and corneal stretching), anisometropia (almost always present in unilateral PCG), optic nerve cupping.

The optic nerve cupping in very young children may be seen solely due to optic canal stretching and posterior bowing of the lamina cribrosa without a decrease in the neuroretinal rim.[42][43] When the IOP is normalized, there can be a notable reversal of cupping. While cupping may resolve, retinal nerve fiber layer damage, if present, is permanent. In older children and those with advanced glaucoma, cupping occurs due to neuroretinal rim tissue loss, especially at the vertical disk poles.[8]

Any asymmetry between the eyes in the aforementioned signs should raise suspicion of glaucoma. Lastly, amblyopia, either deprivation or both, may also be present with the other signs mentioned above.

Ref: Parson 22/e

questions.text: Shahrukh, with a history of heavy smoking presents to your office with painful ulcerations on his hands and feet. He is hypersensitive to intradermally injected tobacco extract. Which of the following processes is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Thromboangiitis obliterans, also known as Buerger disease, is a vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels involving the arteries, veins, and nerves of extremities resulting in limb ischemia.

Thromboangiitis obliterans include thrombotic, segmental vasculitis of a chronic and inflammatory nature. Histologically, inflammatory thrombi affect arteries and can result in a fibrotic casing of contiguous veins and nerves. Patients are often adult males between ages 25 and 50 with a history of long-term, heavy tobacco use. The condition is associated with a hypersensitivity reaction to intradermally injected tobacco extract.

Other Options:

Option A: Increased endothelial permeability is characteristic of atherosclerosis.

Option B: Necrotizing inflammation involving renal arteries is characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.

Option D: Eosinophil-rich granulomatous inflammation is characteristic of Churg-Strauss syndrome (Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis).

Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 399

questions.text: Parents of a 2.5-year-old child frequently criticize and exert rigid control in many basic activities of the child-like potty training, toy preferences, food choices, etc. This may lead to an arrest in the development of autonomy/ confidence in the child and may develop shame/doubt. Which of the following disorders is postulated to occur due to excessive rigid control in this stage?
questions.solution:
• According to Erik Ericson, in Stage 2 psychosocial development, Autonomy vs Shame/ Doubt, with the development of speech and sphincter and muscular control, the toddler (18 months to 3 years) practices the social modalities of holding on and letting go and experiences the first stirrings of the virtue that Erikson termed will.
  • Much depends on the amount and type of control exercised by adults over the child. Control that is exerted too rigidly or too early defeats the toddler's attempts to develop its own internal controls, and regression or false progression results. Parental control that fails to protect the toddler from the consequences of his or her own lack of self-control or judgment can be equally disastrous to the child's development of a healthy sense of autonomy.
  • Where that ratio is favourable, the child develops an appropriate sense of autonomy and the capacity to 'have and to hold'; where it is unfavourable, doubt and shame will undermine free will.
  • The ruminative and ritualistic behavior of the person with an obsessive-compulsive disorder may be an outcome of the triumph of doubt over autonomy and the subsequent development of a primitively harsh conscience.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 4 Theories of Personality and Psychopathology, Page number 169.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with a history of road traffic accidents came to the emergency department with a complaint of pain in the right lower chest. On examination, the patient is having low spo2, tachycardia, and decreased air entry in the right lower zone. Chest x-ray shows obliteration of 3 rib spaces in the right lower chest with no evidence of broncho vascular markings and fracture of right 5th, 6th, and 7th ribs. What is the first line of treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Chest drains

These are indicated for pneumothorax, pleural effusion, haemothorax or to prevent the collection of fluid or air after thoracotomy. Once the drain has been inserted, it should be connected to an underwater sealed drain. This system allows air to leave the pleural cavity, but it cannot be drawn back in by the negative pressure that is created in the intrathoracic cavity. During the respiratory process, it should be checked that the meniscus of the fluid is swinging, to ensure that the tube is not blocked. Suction can be applied to the venting tube at the bottle whenever there is significant drainage of fluid or air expected. Between 10 and 20 mm of mercury is adequate to obtain a gentle flow of bubbles from the chest cavity.

questions.text: A certain diuretic can also be used topically for the management of glaucoma. It is also used to alkalinize the urine. Which of the following is true about the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The drug being referred to here is the carbonic anhydrase inhibitors such as Acetazolamide, Dorzolamide, Brinzolamide, etc. They are non-competitive, reversible inhibitors of carbonic anhydrase.

It is a sulfonamide derivative that noncompetitively but reversibly inhibits CAse (type II) in PT cells resulting in the slowing of hydration of CO2. This decreases the availability of H+ to exchange with luminal Na+ through the Na+-H+ antiporter. Inhibition of brush border CAse (type IV) retards dehydration of H2CO3 in the tubular fluid so that less CO2 diffuses back into the cells. The net effect is the inhibition of HCO3 (and accompanying Na+) reabsorption in PT. However, the resulting alkaline diuresis is only mild (maximal fractional Na+ loss 5%), because part of the Na+ (but not HCO3) rejected in the PT is reabsorbed at the high capacity TAL segment.

Secretion of H+ by the intercalated cells of DT and CD is also interfered. Though H+ is secreted at this site by an H+-ATPase, it is generated in the cell by CAse mediated reaction. As such, this is a subsidiary site of action of CAse inhibitors. When CAse inhibitors are given, the distal Na+ exchange takes place only with K+ which is lost in excess. For the same degree of natriuresis CAse inhibitors cause the most marked kaliuresis compared to other diuretics. The urine produced under acetazolamide action is alkaline and rich in HCO3 which is matched by both Na+ and K+.

Source- Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 633

choices.text: There is a 95% chance that the difference observed reflects a real difference between the two groups

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the meaning of the p-value?
questions.solution:
In order to understand the idea of the P-value, it is first important to consider the two possible results from any study. For example, the first possibility is that statin A and statin B are equivalent, that is to say on average they will have the same effect. This possibility is known as the null hypothesis. The other possibility is that there is a difference between statin A and statin B, which is to say that on average one will be better than the other. This possibility is known as the alternative hypothesis.

In this study, we see that the group taking statin A does better than the other group, but we do not know if that difference is due to the drugs or whether the difference is due to random chance. Therefore, to decide whether there is a real difference in the drugs, we ask 'What is the likelihood that we would have gotten this result just by random chance if the two drugs are the same(the null hypothesis) ?'. The answer to this question is known as the p-value, which is defined as the likelihood of getting this result or a more extreme result if the null hypothesis is true. The smaller this number, the less likely it is that the result was due to chance alone. Therefore in this case a p-value of 0.052 means that there is only a 5.2% chance that this reduction of 11 or a greater reduction would be seen even if the drugs are the same.

Source:

Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with facial eczema. He has a history of recurrent infections of pneumonia and otitis media. Laboratory measurements of serum immunoglobulins show increased IgE and IgA but decreased IgM. Which of the following additional abnormalities would you expect to observe?
questions.solution:
The patient in the question stem is suffering from Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, a congenital immunodeficiency. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome presents with the classic triad of 'TIE': (1) thrombocytopenic purpura (2) infections (3) eczema.

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an inherited (X-linked) immunodeficiency caused by mutations in the WASP gene. Partial B and T cell deficiency result from defects in a cytoskeletal glycoprotein. A loss of cellular and humoral immune response results. Decreased IgM with increased IgA and IgE are classic findings.

Other Options:

Options B and C: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome typically presents with isolated thrombocytopenia. WBCs and RBCs are not affected.

Option D: Pancreatic insufficiency is observed in cystic fibrosis.

Source:

Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 168

questions.text: An 11-year-old male patient who had a generalized tonic seizure was brought to the pediatric OPD. He was born at term by vaginal delivery, weighing 3700 g. The developmental milestones were reported to be delayed. He had repeated sinus infections, for which no cause had been ascertained. His family history was unremarkable. Physical examination revealed a coarse facial appearance, with small ears, a narrow forehead, and a long face with decreased ear creases. The voice was hypernasal. Chvostek and Trousseau signs were positive. Systemic findings were otherwise normal. Laboratory investigations revealed hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia. Parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels were low. Thyroid hormones, cortisol, and prolactin levels were normal. Other biochemical parameters, blood count, and urine analysis were normal. 24-hour urine calcium was 0.42 (mg/kg/day) (normal <4 mg/kg/day).FISH analysis revealed 22q11 deletion in the child. A failure in the development of which pharyngeal arch can cause these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of hypocalcemia and hypoparathyroidism, along with repeated infections and a FISH analysis revealing 22q11 deletion suggests DiGeorge syndrome.

The clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome can be remembered by the mnemonic CATCH-22

C- Cardiac anomalies

A-Abnormal facies

T-Thymic Aplasia

C-Cardiac anomalies

H-Hypocalcemia

22- 22q11 deletion


It is caused due to failure of differentiation of the III pharyngeal pouch.

Thymus and inferior parathyroids are poorly developed, which causes repeated infections and hypocalcemia respectively.



Source- textbook of clinical embryology, Vishram Singh, 12 edition, page 110

questions.text: Which of the following, if seen microscopically, would indicate that a cell is more likely to recover without permanent damage?
questions.solution:
Cellular swelling is a microscopic pathological finding that indicates that cell injury is likely reversible.

Microscopically, changes in cells with reversible damage include decreased glycogen stores, fatty change, membrane blebbing, nuclear chromatin clumping, and cellular/mitochondrial swelling due to decreased Na/K pump activity. These changes can be reversed with prompt oxygen delivery (reperfusion). Of note, these cells may have an irreversible injury and cell death from reperfusion injury if they were deprived of oxygen for too long.

Other Options:

Option B: Mitochondrial vacuolization indicates irreversible cell injury.

Option C: Nuclear pyknosis or condensation indicates irreversible cell injury.

Option D: Plasma membrane damage indicates irreversible cell injury.

Source:

Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 31

questions.text: The last deformity to be corrected by Ponseti's method for CTEV is -
questions.solution:
Ponseti's technique:-

Ponseti method of choice now with a success rate of > 95%. This procedure consists of manipulating the foot for 1-3 minutes into the corrected position, followed by holding the correction in an above-knee cast (applied with knees flexed to 90°).

After 7 days, the cast is removed, foot re-manipulated, and recasted for another week in a successively more corrected position. Usually, 5 to 7 casts are sufficient and deformity gets corrected.

the order of corrections is very important. It can be remembered by the pneumonic

'CAVE'. Cavus is corrected in the 1st cast by supinating the forefoot and dorsiflexing the 1st metatarsal.

Forefoot must never be pronated as it will increase the cavus deformity. Adduction and varus are then corrected simultaneously in the subsequent casts by abducting the forefoot in supination with counter

pressure being applied at the talar head.

Lastly, equinus is corrected, by dorsiflexing the fully abducted foot.

In case dorsiflexion is difficult beyond neutral then a percutaneous tenotomy of Tendo Achilles is done to achieve adequate dorsiflexion.

Ref: Maheshwari Ortho 5TH Edition Page no: 214.

questions.text: Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for the diagnosis of which of the following Conditions?
questions.solution:
The sabin-Feldman dye test is used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis.

T is based on the principle that the presence of anti-toxoplasma antibodies in the patients.

Serum inhibits the staining of trophozoites by alkaline methylene blue dye.

Toxoplasma trophozoites and complement are added to the patient's serum which is then

Incubated for an hour at 37C. After incubation, methylene blue dye is added.

Lf ant-toxoplasma antibodies are present in the serum, these are activated by complement and the parasite membrane is lysed. Thus, the trophozoites are not stained (positive result).

If there are no antibodies, trophozoites will take up the stain and appear blue under the Microscope. This is considered to be a negative result.

The dilution of the test serum at which 50% of the tachyzoites are not stained is reported as the Antibody titer of the test serum. The test is highly sensitive and specific.

It cannot differentiate between recent or past infections as it detects only lgG antibodies.

Reference:

Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology 8th edition Page no: 95

questions.text: You are conducting a study on hypertension in 60 adults. The mean systolic blood pressure is 140 mmHg, and the standard deviation is 7 mmHg, how many participants would you expect to have systolic blood pressure between 126 and 154 mmHg?
questions.solution:
In a normally distributed sample, 95% of the observations are expected to fall within 2 standard deviations of the mean.

The utility of using normal curves in biostatistics is relying on specific characteristics of the normal distribution. Because this sample's standard deviation is 7 mmHg, the values of 154 and 126 mmHg are each 2 standard deviations above and below the mean of 140 mmHg, e.g. (154-140)/7 = 2. Because the sample is normally distributed we can reasonably assume that 95% of the participants will fall within +/- 2 standard deviations of the mean, i.e. 0.95 x 60 = 57 participants.

Source:

Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, by K. Park, 26th Edition, Page Number 60

questions.text: Which of the following biomarkers is seen after kidney injury in a patient undergoing cardiopulmonary bypass within 2 hours?
questions.solution:
Neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin (NGAL, also known as lipocalin-2 or siderocalin) is another novel biomarker of AKI. NGAL was first discovered as a protein in granules of human neutrophils. NGAL can bind to iron siderophore complexes and may have tissue-protective effects in the proximal tubule. NGAL is highly upregulated after inflammation and kidney injury and can be detected in the plasma and urine within 2 h of cardiopulmonary bypass-associated AKI.

Kidney injury molecule-1 (KIM-1) is a type 1 transmembrane protein that is abundantly expressed in proximal tubular cells injured by ischemia or nephrotoxins such as cisplatin.

In 2014, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved the marketing of a test based on the combination of the urinary concentrations of two cell-cycle arrest biomarkers, insulin-like growth factor binding protein 7 (IGFBP7) and tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinase-2 (TIMP-2) as predictive biomarkers for higher risk of the development of moderate to severe AKI in critically ill patients.

questions.text: A 26-year-old medical student who is preparing for NEET-PG realizes that she has not eaten for over 2 days. Which of the following sets of organs are associated with the major source of energy currently facilitating her cognition?
questions.solution:
The major source of glucose in this patient who has been fasting for around 24 hours is gluconeogenesis, which occurs in both the liver and the kidney.

During the first two hours after a meal, the main source of circulating glucose is the absorption of the exogenously consumed glucose by enterocytes.

Between 4 and 12 hours after eating, the main source of circulating glucose becomes glycogenolysis within the liver.

Finally, more than 16 hours after the last meal, the main source of circulating glucose is gluconeogenesis, which occurs in the liver as well as the kidneys.

Importantly, even though muscle tissue has substantial glucose deposits, it lacks the ability to release this glucose into the blood so it does not contribute to circulating glucose.

Source:

Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, by DM Vasudevan, 9th Edition, Page Number 549

questions.text: A patient complains of dysphagia, halitosis, and regurgitation. His barium swallow study reveals that there is a collection of dye posterior to the esophagus. Between which of the following muscles did the dye most likely enter the collection from the esophagus?
questions.solution:
This patient with dysphagia, regurgitation, halitosis and a posterior collection on barium swallow most likely has a Zenker diverticulum, which is a protrusion between the inferior pharyngeal constrictor and cricopharyngeus muscles.

A Zenker diverticulum is a false diverticulum of the esophagus that occurs primarily in male patients over 60 years of age. Zenker diverticulum is usually caused by motor abnormalities of the esophagus and involves mucosal protrusion at the junction of the pharynx and the esophagus. This area of muscular weakness, known as the Killian triangle, is located between the two bellies of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor, namely the cricopharyngeus and the thyropharyngeus. This protrusion can catch food leading to the classic symptoms of dysphagia, regurgitation, and halitosis.

Other Options:

Option A: The area between the circular and longitudinal muscle of the esophagus does not allow for the diverticula because this is not an area of muscle weakness.

Option B: The area between the cricopharyngeus and the circular muscle of the esophagus is known as the Laimer triangle; however, this is not as common a place for protrusion as the Killian triangle.

Option D: The area between the superior and inferior pharyngeal constrictors does not allow for diverticuli because this is not an area of muscle weakness.

Source:

Robbins Basic Pathology by Kumar, Abbas, and Aster, 10th Edition, Page Number 583

questions.text: A patient presented with altered sensorium, slurring of speech, and unilateral limb weakness for 3 hours. He underwent a CT scan which is shown below. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
Stroke-a generic term meaning sudden onset of a neurologic event-is also referred to as a cerebrovascular accident (CVA) or 'brain attack'. Acute strokes are those 6-48 hours from onset. The most specific but least sensitive sign is a hyperattenuating vessel filled with acute thrombus. A 'dense MCA' sign. Blurring and indistinctness of grey-white matter (GM-WM) interfaces can be seen in 50-70% of cases within the first 3 hours following occlusion. Loss of the insular cortex ('insular ribbon' sign) and decreased density of the basal ganglia ('disappearing basal ganglia' sign) are the most common findings. Wedge-shaped parenchymal hypodensity with indistinct GM-WM borders and cortical sulcal effacement develops in large territorial occlusions.

The given image shows a dense MCA sign and the patient should undergo thrombolysis or mechanical thrombectomy.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 Brain edition 2 pg 212

questions.solution:
The four basic brain waveforms are alpha, beta, delta, and theta.

  • Alpha waves with a frequency range of 8 to 13 Hz constitute the dominant brain wave frequency of the normal eyes-closed awake EEG.
  • Frequencies that are faster than the upper 13 Hz limit of the alpha rhythm are termed beta waves, and they are commonly seen in normal adult awake and aroused states.
  • Delta waves (<3.5 Hz) are not present in the normal waking EEG but are a prominent feature of deeper stages of sleep. The presence of significant generalized or focal delta waves in the awake EEG is strongly indicative of a pathophysiological process.
  • Waves with a frequency of 4.0 to 7.5 Hz are collectively referred to as theta waves. It is a prominent feature in a drowsy state. Excessive theta in awake EEG, generalized or focal in nature, suggests the operation of a pathological process.


Figure: Brain waveforms

Reference:Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 1 Neural Sciences, page no. 86

questions.text: Which of the following is not a use of somatostatin analogues?
questions.solution:
It is secreted by the hypothalamus, GIT as well as by δ-cells of the pancreas. It inhibits the secretion of GH, TSH, prolactin, insulin, glucagon, gastrin, and HCl.

  • It is indicated for the management of acromegaly, islet cell tumors, bleeding due to esophageal varices, and secretory diarrhea but has the disadvantage of a short duration of action.
  • Octreotide is a somatostatin analogue having high potency and a long duration of action. It is preferred over somatostatin for all indications.
  • Octreotide also inhibits TSH secretion and is the treatment of choice for TSH-secreting adenoma in patients who are not candidates for surgery.
  • Lanreotide is another somatostatin analog that can be given i.m. in a slow-release formulation
  • Vapreotide, pasireotide, and seglitide are other somatostatin analogs.

Prolactin analogues like bromocriptine can be used for parkinsonism.

Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by K D Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page No. 259

questions.text:
A person living with HIV presents with subacute dyspnea. His respiratory examination was nonspecific. However, his O2 saturation was low. The figure shows the histology.

The figure shows direct microscopy of Pneumocystis pneumonia.

B. Methenamine silver-stain bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid.

C. Giemsa-stained BAL fluid.

D. Immunofluorescent stain of BAL fluid



PCP presents as acute or subacute pneumonia that may initially be characterized by a vague sense of dyspnea alone but that subsequently manifests as fever and nonproductive cough with progressive shortness of breath, ultimately resulting in respiratory failure and death. Extrapulmonary manifestations of PCP are rare but can include the involvement of almost any organ, most notably lymph nodes, spleen, and liver.

Physical Examination The physical examination findings in PCP are nonspecific. Patients have decreased oxygen saturation-at rest or with exertion-that, without treatment, progresses to severe hypoxemia. Patients may initially have a normal chest examination and no adventitious sounds, but later develop diffuse rales and signs of consolidation.

questions.text: Given below are substances matched with potential consequences of chronic abuse. Identify the wrong match
questions.solution:
Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) does not produce physical dependence.

Other substances of abuse that do not produce physical dependence include cocaine, cannabis, and amphetamines. The potential consequences of chronic abuse of LSD are flashbacks or bad trips.

Physical dependence: Frequent exposure to the drug leads to an altered neurophysiological state. This is characterized by the emergence of tolerance to the drug as well as withdrawal symptoms when the chronically abused drug is discontinued.

Other options:

Option A: Korsakoff syndrome is seen with chronic alcohol abuse. It is characterized by anterograde and retrograde amnesia, disorientation, and confabulation (describing fabricated experiences to fill gaps in memory).

Option B: Amotivational syndrome is seen with chronic cannabis abuse. It is characterized by lethargy and reduced interest in day-to-day activities.

Option D: Tactile hallucinations seen with cocaine abuse. The affected individual perceives small insects creeping on the skin, giving rise to itching sensations. These hallucinations are termed cocaine bugs or Magnan's symptoms.

References

Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice 5th edition

Page no. 510

questions.text: A regular contact lens user presents with complaints of severe pain, photophobia, and blurring of vision for more than two weeks not responding to standard treatment.
